Also, meta-topic: I love that this team exists, but I also think there needs to be a publicly accessible place for Slack development. Maybe I'm just not plugged in — see previous comment about the original C++-preprocessor — but Slack development feels scattered and one-shot right now. There's no community that I'm aware of. People are doing great stuff, but there's no gathering place for de facto standards and consensus best-practices to emerge. Maybe it's too early for that, but I think Slack development is going to be huge and I'd love to see good people stake a claim to the core of it.

I wrote Ben an e-mail this morning about what my plans were before my current non-Slack project got off the ground, and I still think it's a good idea:
Your email inspired me to set up this team btw
1) Slackbot host as a service. For companies that love Slack, but don't have the time, interest or skills to go to Github, grab the source, compile it and start a Heroku intance.
For a company already paying for Slack, $20/month for hosting bots would be an easy decision.
And via the Hubot integration, there are _hundreds_ of bots.
I even wrote some code to run multiple Hubot integrations with per-team configs.
:thumbsup::skin-tone-3::thumbsup::skin-tone-3::thumbsup::skin-tone-3:
2) Slack consultancy, not only doing custom integrations with internal systems, but best-practices (including stuff for the lawyers with company IP going off-site, SEC-compliance and auditing, etc.).
IMHO should use the same pricing model as slack - per user
If Slack goes mainstream, there are going to be a lot of companies that will need it supported. Not just the base product, but adding everything that they'll suddenly become capable of doing with it.
They will have _no_ idea.
Yup
And anyone who can show them just a little glimpse of what's possible is going to be drowning in the work of implementing it.
We already are seeing this in our consultancy as I'd
As is
Every project we've done this year had a slack component
And is better because of it
And required less UI to be built
And was better because of that too!
The biggest obstacle I see between Slack and domination of — God forgive me — “the enterprise” is off-site storage and hierarchical corporate culture.
Years ago, I was at a mutual fund company and we wanted to use Basecamp and Legal threw a fit.
<@U04S09GLN> can maybe speak to that a bit?
“The Cloud” has changed some of that as people have gotten more used to it, but old-school companies are still leery of anything going outside the VPN.
At that same company, I built an intranet that was specifically designed for cross-departmental and cross-organizational sharing, and… Well, the managers hated it.
_Hated_ it.
Slack allows the same thing, and I see that as a cultural barrier.
But so many non-tech companies are small enough or forward-thinking enough to want Slack and want it badly, that I think it's going to spread like crazy.
Even without the older, larger organizations.
And every one of them could have their already terrific experience improved by a handful of well-chosen bots.

You guys and your “west coast” timezone / late work hours.
Yeah, we have almost 800 users in our Dow Jones slack. Definitely not 100% penetration in the company yet, but my team is working on that every day.

That's really impressive. I worked for Dimensional Fund Advisors, and in the seven years I was there, the company went from very casual, very cross-discipline, very get-the-job-done to much more formalized and hierarchical. It also went from $50B AUM to $300B AUM, so that might have had something to do with it. But the culture got… tight. I managed to get IM in — after an exhausting fight — and one department head said he didn't want people from outside his department to be able to contact his workers. Maybe that's biasing my take, but Slack tears down walls and Dimensional was busy putting them up.
And every tool we're building these days, at least in my team, all involve slack.
A new photo workflow tool for the photo department now allows you to share selected photos

the Share dialog creates a private slack channel to discuss those photos, invites people you ask in the same dialog, sets the description, and posts a link back to the tool's unique url for that collection
Next step is photo approval from the private slack channel
<@U04S2TZMU> we had built our own internal chat product before, DJChat, so everyone was already in on the idea of how chat fit into a workflow, and helped break down walls.
I think part of the reason it's been successful is that my team and another collaborated on systematically onboarding everyone into slack with a reason to be there, for the first 100 people
where, every time a new project would start, we'd set up the appropriate channels and invite everyone to them.
They'd arrive, and find a whole open community of internal channels already in existence, and never leave. Then they'd do the same thing for subsequent projects.
So coooool

And now, we've hooked up <http://slackline.io|slackline.io> to get a public dev channel across the senior tech leadership of the corporation, which is the first time a) that we've ever had a way of sharing information efficiently across different company units, and b) the first public discussion forum for the whole corporation.
Careful or you are going to end up a case study
This is all super interesting! Thanks for sharing, <@U04S09GLN>.

Can you give an example of the interaction between slash command and responses? How does it help make decisions?
Thanks, buster!
We use the slash command to set up a decision.
Right now it would be something like “/caslo Should we put a picture of a cat on the front page?"
Slackbot whispers back to you “Click here <https://decidewithcaslo.com/xyz123/> to finish setting up your decision."
The details are completed in a web browser, and from then on the caslo bot interacts with the channel.

Ah, got it. Seems like a common pattern to have a quick setup and then use incoming webhooks to post updates back. After setup, can you continue to interact with the decision through slack? For example, can you vote on xyz123?

I spent Sunday working on a file command handling bot. The idea is that you make commands within a file's comment stream that will fire off events for that file. I ended up rabbit holing a bit when I decided to learn more about Python's new asyncio and go sans web framework (usually tornado), and spent more time setting up the thing than actually making it do anything useful. Ultimately settled on using Autobahn for the websockets.
At this point it's opening the websocket, listening for commands on file comments and direct messaging the user who made the command (for more info?). Hope to get back to it a bit throughout the week on the evenings

<@U04SM6T2H>: Good read. Interesting about doing the standup in parallel. But isn't there some benefit for doing it "serially"? sometimes I hear what others said before me, and it makes me change my mind about what I was going to say

I had a similar reaction to <@U055FHACC> about the standup bot… for me, standups are more about listening and helping others who are blocked or pondering something unresolved as they are about me presenting my status. Bots can help with the writing, but not the listening and helping parts. That said, I think there's a lot of invisible time saved by just not having to wait for everyone to meet in person, return from meetings, VC in remote people, etc. Maybe moving to a virtual standup actually would save 13 minutes, but they would come from a bunch of things that people don't even think of as taking time or being work.
I should have started with: overall though I love the post! :simple_smile:

I'd also add, in the context of our own bot, when scheduling meeting we had to weight in the benefits of doing it in parallel (as you described, buy mainly for the reason of trying not to spam the channel with scheduling talk), vs. doing it all on the channel. We chose (for now, at least) to do it all on-channel because seeing what others are choosing helps the team converge into one preference and aids the scheduling process
So if I see that two people before me preferred a meeting to happen on Thursday, I'd go with that too. Even if initially I was thinking that Wednesday is better
Yeah, we have a bot that justs make sure we go in order, and that everything is recorded, topics that are tabled are returned to, etc.

I knew a guy years ago, and he had a start-up that provided homework help. Kids would come home from school, have trouble, login and get a live tutor to walk them through the problems.
It wasn't working.
The tutors would spend most of their time waiting and then get crushed.
And so he brute-forced it.
He built an iPad app where the tutor would solve the problem, recording his voice as he did so.
And set them loose on the math textbooks for California and Texas, which are basically the two states that control what goes into our educational system.
And a month or so later, he had tutorial videos for every problem at every grade for (nearly) every public school.
And then he just hosted the videos, not going back to the live tutors.

like, my bot Harmonia says “James Adam has been assigned a task!”, and then if I say “@harmonia done”, the bot needs to look at what it knows about my team, who I am in Slack vs who I am in the app, and then what task I might've been refering to, before it can actually do something concrete

<http://www.sas.upenn.edu/~haroldfs/dravling/grice.html>

For other integrations I've build (like Trello), I've had to get users to fill in some of the mapping between the service and my app, but with something like Slack, there's an interesting opportunity to make the bot “learn” (in the weakest sense) about how the two apps relate in a gradual way

So when I say “@harmonia done”, and the bot doesn't know who I am in Harmonia, it might open a DM at that point and say “Oh hello there. Before I can mark your task as done, I need to know a little more about you. I'm guessing that you're <james@lazyatom.com> in Harmonia - is that right?"
and so on - building up the mapping by asking questions at the last minute

but was not sure

<@U06UZ1RKQ>: I keep track of the user's conversation with the bot via their Slack user ID. The bot will ask the first question and then the user will respond. I update that conversation in my DB with the user's response. Then based on that response, the bot will ask another question and record that response in the DB with the user's response again. Once the bot has asked a series of questions and recorded the responses, the bot does what ever functionality you want it to do (API requests, google searches, etc.). After the bot responds with the final answer/solution the user is looking for, the bot just updates that converstation/record in the DB to say that it is complete. The next time that Slack user ID initiates the slash command for that bot, the whole process starts over again because the last "converstation" is marked as complete in the DB.
It might not be the solution your looking for…depending on how in depth you want the conversation to get with the user

<@U07K5QQDN>: what kind of tools are you talking about?
Ability to set team needs, find people that can fill the needs on the team, to work with people know or find those you don't.
Very much along the lines of podular teams in the Connected Company book that I co-authored with Dave Gray. But, can fit other models as well.

Years back I ran things this way in spreadsheets, but helping clients in the last 10 years a couple times we've built small internal apps to do this. Because of the book I'm finding it may be time to do something that maps how larger orgs do this (to augment and integrate with the many tools they have) as well as smaller teams.

Anyone other than me has tackled time zone names of Slack? With Slack API, you can see people from US east coast as 'America/Indiana/Indianapolis' time zone, not 'America/New_York' (Both are UTC -4). Also you see people from Europe are all fallen into 'Europe/London' or 'Europe/Amsterdam' or 'EET'. It looks like, Slack is just assigning a zone of same offset, without caring much about country of the time zone. But maybe caring continents? South and North American people are not mixed.
if you fall into one of these _wrong_ time zone, you can change it at <https://rubyonrails-link.slack.com/account/settings>, but selection is still limited (see HTML source of select tag)
well, maybe Slack can only know client's time offset, and guessing time zone label from that?

That's the thing, they can only guess your timezone offset from your browser when you create your account (Browser privacy prevents better info). Theoretically, they could combine IP + offset to have a better guess.
The direct link to change the timezone (if you want to send your users) is <https://my.slack.com/account/settings#timezone> . It will redirect to their team (instead of the rubyonrails-link).

<@U0563E81H> thanks for explanation. and correct link. I was trying to stat my team's distribution from time zone names, but it's not very reliable. I also found Russian people are classified as Asia/Kuwait and west Australian are set as Asia/Ulaanbaatar. that's bad.
however, Europe vs Africa and South vs North America looks labeled correctly.
<@U08AK3DQ8>: America/Indiana/Indianapolis is a valid timezone, because Indiana touches two different time zones (Central & Eastern)

I had a trigger in when I was near a CVS that was “Drug! Don't forget the drugs!”, but I marked it complete at some point.
My Skype rings and says “Get dressed you moron, X is calling” which after 8 years still sets a little panic on Skype calls.

Many years back in early Twitter days I would sign out of twitter each night with “good night off to read and sleep - zzzz” and I had an automation that would start reading my Twitter feed each night at 9pm for that phrase and then turn off sound on my computer (I had it read and talk to me a fair amount, my now ex was freaked out by voices in the house at night).
The next morning when I would turn on sound through an action would ask “Good morning. Well rested?"
Yeah I use location based reminders to get my phone to say "welcome home Captain!!"
And welcome to work
For me this stuff needs to be the norm and really should be here.

Now I'm wanting to rebuild some of these again. The geofencing needs to be a little better as sometimes I will be miles away from home and my proximity message for home will trigger. I really want the phone to say “Woops, that was a false alarm. Sorry about that.” It knows it was an error, it must.
I did have a “you have your son with you, right?” set for 10 minutes after I should have picked him up from school and trigged if I wasn't near his school.

Having smart fuzzy alarms for things like returning library books would be good. Also phrasing things like “do you have your library book with you?” or “are you done reading your library book or do you want to get an extension?” would be much better than “your library book is due”. Enough with command statements and more of soft helpful reminders, particularly if they can extend my library book due date for me.

As a staring point, what language / framework would you all suggest for building a custom slack bot. I guess there are a few options and I am looking for something that isn't overly complex. I was though of thinking python, but didn't want to start out on one route if it is totally pointless and there are better routes to go down. I think there are a few ruby fans here, but its not something I have much experience with.

I gave a presentation about slack bots in Python last week, but the video isn't up yet. I think you have to decide what your goal is with the bot (deploying it for other people in lots of slack accounts, just focused on your slack room, or your team?). If you enjoy writing code and want to learn about the API and tinker with it, building something yourself in Python can totally work. If you want to eventually deploy it at scale for a bunch of people, you're going to end up needing to pull in some event driven stuff in python to do that, and if it grows enough, you may wish you'd picked node.js or elixir or golang.
Here's my repo about Python slack bots, though: <https://github.com/jeffk/PyBot>
<@U0B5YQ7EY>: me = biased, but in Ruby it's super easy with <https://github.com/dblock/slack-ruby-bot>, basically no boilerplate code
Yea, I think it really comes down to 1. what you're comfortable with and 2. the scale you're deploying at

have used slack-ruby-bot before and it's awesome. If you're looking for something that is meant to be used as a “bot-as-a-service (serving multiple teams)”, im working on relax: <http://relax.zerobotlabs.com|relax.zerobotlabs.com>, going to be on github soon :simple_smile:

This is what I am thinking, I am thinking of custom integrations for specific teams. So lets say a client sets up slack and has some specific events or integrations, maybe from legacy or bespoke systems, I want to able to say “no problem” I can create a bot to do that. At this stage, I'm just thinking about effectively an acedemic excercise for myself to get comfortable with the Slack API. I have already built a WordPress plugin that deals with the API, (in PHP of course) without issue. My background is C, C++ and scripting languages such as Perl, Python & PHP. To be frank I have hardly ever heard of node.js or elixir or golang so have no idea about the pro & cons there.
That said, if I find ‘custom integration' become something bigger then that would be an opportunity, I guess

<@U0BSHTG0P>: If you reload your client, your disappearing notifications should be fixed.

:rocket:
<@U0BSHTG0P>: I've used the open-source Gluster that's distributed with Ubuntu 14.04.
I can't say I'm an expert, because it's a particularly deep hole to go down, but I've been a largely happy user over the past three years for multiple deployments.
what kind of stuff are you doing with it?
I don't know what Red Hat adds, if anything, but the free version works well.
if i may pry.

Redundantly hosting a shared filesystem. [A large city-based blogging network], for instance, publishes its articles as static PHP to a two-brick (multi-AWS AZ) Gluster cluster, and multiple EC2 instances of Apache mount the Gluster volume and serve the files.
Varnish takes most of the load and the actual filesystem use is read-heavy, write-rarely.
But compared to s3fs, it's miles faster. Compared to commercial solutions, it's miles cheaper.
indeed.
I'm eager to see what AWS's EFS looks like, but Gluster has served me well for three years.
i've got a different use case
for distributed storage for virtual machines
so write is definitely going to be happening
looking at cheaper ways to build and scale convergence
Write is a lot slower than local or single-volume filesystems, but my biggest Gluster installation is hosting 400G of data, so it _does_ handle pretty large volumes.
Just not _fast_.
hm.
this is something im building locally on commodity hardware
the question we're kind of stewing on is how we handle the replication all the way down
are we presenting a raid array as the initial mount point with hardware raid

I think groups are used less for us as we are a small team all working on the same thing, so everything is basically company wide
Here is our data: 18% were in channels, 6% were in groups and 76% were direct messages
All time statistics - 12% #channels, 11% groups, 76% DMs

Slack folks: have you considered using an optional sender whitelist approach for the Slack email integration? Using a hash email address <mailto:fdfdsf32r32r@myteam.slack.com|fdfdsf32r32r@myteam.slack.com> is a lot of friction, would be better if it could be aliased as <mailto:mychannel@myteam.slack.com|mychannel@myteam.slack.com> or something like that.

It would also be great if it took whatever text was added at the top of forwarded emails and used that as the message text in the slack post. Having everything buried in an email attachment is a lot less readable at a glance.
also hello <@U0CJ50JV6> :simple_smile:
i just created a contact/alias in our email system <mailto:mychannel@mycompany.com|mychannel@mycompany.com> and that forwards along to the email integration
<@U0BSHTG0P>: right, good point. Just seems like an extra step vs. forwarding to services like kindle or remember the milk which have human readable addresses.
i would venture a guess that they addresses are unique IDs
and they're not providing you a dedicated email parsing server that would allow for unique amongst yourself
they have services collectively parsing for all
also, you can change your team's slack name
So if you went from companya to companyb, right now it wouldn't matter if they're just scraping a unique ID
but if they were validating your entire address because the user portion of your email is unique, that could be a little slippery
also…heh…from my use, it appears there's no junk filtering
so an easier address may very well get scraped or discovered and be dumping more overhead into their system
Right - I get why they are doing it, just suggesting other services have a way to satisfy those requirements...
can't they keep the id and aliases?

Hi! I'm looking for advice about the easiest way to do something:
We want to maintain a connection to the RTM API and write messages (for a ~10 person slack group) to a database. Preference for Python, but could be convinced otherwise. I found a Python wrapper called slacksocket on github, and I have that up and running on my local machine listening to messages. As far as deploying it somewhere, heroku seems like the obvious choice, but I don't really understand how setting up sockets from heroku would work. Anyone have experience with this?
there's nothing special about heroku
well i am just right now working with hubot and hubot-slack adapter, so that out of the way, it should be easy to find a npm package that connects easily to your database of choice
websockets work normally
well yeah, heroku is just a hosting service in the end, right?
yup
so my point is, whatever normal way python does websockets should work
true that
if you use heroku you can just set your procfile to use a `worker` rather than `web` dyno

Okay, so just deploy the same Python script on heroku, and the websockets should be the same? Will it handle reconnecting if it gets disconnected? What does using a worker dyno instead of a web dyno do?
well if it reconnects in your script, it acts the exact same way on heroku
and for worker i can only assume, that it will just be executed, rather than with web it will be activated when it is being selected, browsed to, amirite?
Oh that makes sense. Thanks! I'll try it out.
i never used heroku, this is just a presumption
yeah, I haven't been using heroku lately but when I did it behaved oddly if I tried to use a web dyno with RTM because it expects a web server

Hey guys, we are working on a startup that will bring order to today's chaotic workflows, connecting almost everything you use to manage your entire business or just simply your projects or maybe invocies and team (you pick) in one place. Truly intuitive, fast, accessible from anywhere and deeply customizable.
(it will integrate with slack)
It is time for the tools to work YOUR way.
I can't really reveal any more for a little while yet, but hope this gives you an idea?
We are trying to settle on a name for it.
It is currently called Pluto "project code" and we like the name, but obviously marketing it is going to be extremely challenging! we have the domain <http://usepluto.com|usepluto.com>
However, we also have the name Nodello (node + ello).
Node = a point in a network at which lines or pathways intersect or branch.
In our system, we are the central node that connects everything to everything else.
Ello = in english it is a short cut for "hello", and in spanish it translates to "that".
So, NodELLO can mean; hello to new nodes "new services / connections / integration etc...".
NodeTHAT(ello) can mean integrate with THAT (that = systems and third parties etc..).
Nodello also sound as Nutella, tasty and smooth.
What do you guys reckon? thanks for any help!
I have registered the domain <http://usepluto.com|usepluto.com>, so we can call it Pluto and use the domain <http://usepluto.com|usepluto.com>? but I still really think it is going to be challenging to market it.
So, Nodello or Pluto (usepluto) what do you guys reckon? thanks ^.^

<@U04S1QCPC> <@U04SS2NBF> quick feedback on the new OAuth: Having more granular OAuth permissions is good, I think when done right this will lower the bar for some companies to auth in apps. I think the UI for showing what permissions an app is asking for could be done a bit better. The net effect seems to be that it is better to ask for wider permissions, because asking for fine grained ones creates a long scary list for the user. Maybe combining more permission requests in a smaller form factor or removing the yellow warnings would have the desired effect.
<@U0CS6NSF5>: at minimum an empty 200 is required on the initial response
<@U0554MQJB>: we're working on exactly what you mentioned at the end (combining similar-ish things), should be out soon hopefully.

Hi folks, do the new OAuth scopes described at <https://medium.com/slack-developer-blog/new-and-improved-oauth-scopes-4894b2cc159d> apply to on-boarding of bots that use the RTM API? So far we've been telling users to create a bot user and give us the API token. Is that still the flow even after this OAuth update?
does anyone know if it's possible to circumvent slack's own onboarding process with slackbot? we want to build our own onboarding bot instead.

I'll be curious of the Slack onboarding could be extended to cover the new custom profile fields options. (Ideally we're hoping to be able to import from Google Contacts into Slack so it's an automatic process, but we haven't explored it *yet*)
<@U0D7C5RAL>: what do you mean by import from Google Contacts into Slack? Like invite a set of people from Google into your Slack team?

Importing data, I think is more the idea. As in, we have Google Apps for Work for the company, so in our onboarding process data's already going in there. We'd like to avoid adding more steps to onboarding for manual data entry (And keeping things synced would be handy), but having the data available in Slack would be useful. Since we're using domain sign-on & Google Auth, there should be a 1:1 mapping between Google Contacts data and Slack profiles.
<@U06MHAMFT>: that's still the way, yes, no way to attach a bot to your application yet
(Alternately, extending Slackbot's default onboarding to ask things like *Who is your manager?* *What department are you in?*, *What team are you on?* would be the manual equivalent)
thanks <@U0CS6NSF5>

<@U0D7C5RAL>: I think it's a good idea what you're trying to do, but FYI, technically speaking the user profile fields that go together with each user in Google Apps are not Contacts, but rather profile fields tied to the Google account. So what you're asking for is to actually pull profile info from a Google Account rather that from Google Contacts
Ah, gotcha. That makes sense. Thanks for the clarification there. `Google Account => Slack Profile`

I've been looking for a way to do this as well. We use OneLogin as our cloud directory as a service / single sign on (sudo LDAP) and we provision users out automatically to Google apps and Slack. However the Profile info has to be manually added in slack, but name, username, and email transfer perfectly.

I'm guessing that the Real Time Messaging API creates one WebSocket between my server and the Slack channel. If I'm monitoring multiple Slack channels with a single web server, then there are multiple WebSockets open.
How many Slack channels can the average server on Heroku (or a similar platform) handle at once? What are the factors which affect the load on the server and WebSocket the most–is it the number of Slack users connected to the channel or is it rate of the messages between them that matters?
<@U0EJEUZRD>: the RTM API is per team rather than per channel
with regards to how many web sockets you can handle with a Heroku server, it depends a lot on the language and libraries you use to make the connection

<@U0CS6NSF5>: Thank you for that clarification about team rather than channel. I'm trying to get a grasp on a very rough estimate for how many WebSockets per server: 1/10/100/1000/etc. Do channels with twice the amount of activity require twice the bandwidth? I would guess so.
I will do it myself and share the results back here, but I was hoping that someone might already have an answer for a general estimate like that.
<@U0EJEUZRD>: we run thousands per small dyno using Go and our own library
<@U0EJEUZRD>: I have seen (which I am trying to find) of 6000 websocket connections per dyno
<@U0CS6NSF5> and <@U0AFABJAJ> Thanks–that is very helpful! And it's great news to see that one server can handle so much.
<http://veldstra.org/2013/10/25/heroku-websocket-performance-test.html> (with Node)
we do shard requests across different dynos to avoid having everything running in single dyno. That way any potential crash doesn't bring all the connections down
But like <@U0CS6NSF5> says, it definitely depends on the language (and code)
also, bear in mind one thing, most of the info you are going to read about websockets and heroku talk about heroku as a websocket server rather than a client

Hey folks, how do you handle Slack rate limit?

<@U0F1Z87JT>: We slow down :simple_smile: We try not to pass the limit even for a short while. So, first of all, we batch most of the text into a single message (users prefer that also, instead of a trillion dings). Then, we keep a last-sent-time per team, and requeue all messages that are sent too fast.
<@U0563E81H>: Which queue are you using?
For that, just an internal one, nothing complex.
Without storing users & checking for changes, are there any ways to know if a user is new to the team?
<@U04S6E9EW>: no
You could track users joining <#C04SM6TAK>.
It actually looks like there's a _team_join_ event that does what we're looking for.
<https://api.slack.com/events/team_join>
<@U04S6E9EW>: but it's not a method to query whether a user is new, you need to be connected when the event is triggered in order to know about it
so you should still store and check for changes in case the user joins while you are disconnected
if you want to know _when a user joins_ you can use team_join, but to check if a given user is “new” you'll have to store information, and you should probably store some information anyway

You can render `<@ID>` and slack client will translate those into the usernames. Otherwise you have to ask slack for the user info for each ID.
oh wow, didn't know that!
cool
That's indeed pretty awesome!
channels act the same btw :wink:
so just have the bot type <@U0A2E9FJQ>

Yep. If you do want the username, in slack-gamebot I store that and also listen to `user_change` events (here: <https://github.com/dblock/slack-gamebot/blob/5003acb599aa8c47c6a0dab06abe4fa867b93756/slack-gamebot/hooks/user_change.rb>) and also update this info every time a user talks to the bot.
<@U0GPSB7V1>: also, since you are using the RTM API, you would normally have all the users in memory which means you can get the user corresponding to that ID without using the REST API
how would i get them in memory?
You'd have to load them in through the web API

any opinions on posting bot messages using WEB API versus the RTM API? I've got a bot listening in RTM stream but thinking of replying back with Web API.
<@U0H0MPM6U>: If you can reply via the RTM API, it's wasteful to open more connections and what not. It will work though.
<@U0H0MPM6U>: you'll find the web API far more flexible for posting messages vs. RTM. RTM only handles simple text messages, `chat.postMessage` allows for attachments, linking names, etc.
replying via the WEB API is a couple of orders of magnitude slower too
if you want your bot to reply with web api then it needs two tokens, right? on for RTM and one for Web?
<@U0GPSB7V1>: nope, the bot token access token also gives you access to certain methods in the API, including chat.postMessage

<@U055FHACC> we track each 'conversation' seperately within a request, and we know the contex/input we are expecting. If a comment doesn't match the expected input for the newest conversation, and isn't a trigger for a new conversation, it walks back through previous conversations that are still active to find a match (it can walk through 'n' but we limit it to 3 to avoid user confusion) eg:

<@U0CNYC404>: I think I understand (still curious to see an example when you can). but I'm thinking about same-kind events, like: Joey invited you to a meetings. You can `accept` or `decline` [A minute later] Dan invited you to a a meeting. You can `accept` or `decline`

we track each user/channel combo separately at the moment (as different requests), going to add an option for it to just be each channel for those that want to interact in one conversation if it's requested. Okay, but if you have User A,B and Bot C. and user A and B are chatting. You don't want C to chime in after each request with “I don't understand"

depends entirely on how someone wants to set it up (e.g if it's @botname) then you would want it to reply with ‘I don't understand', if it's monitoring everything, you wouldn't
This is an interesting challenge and primary only applicable to bots in channels unlike SMS and the role they must play. Moderator vs Percipient

perhaps you could use a command to trigger one behavior or the other?

A quick question for Slack devs (actual Slack devs):
It is actually possible to anonymously post to a Slack group by just going to `<https://slack.com/api/chat.postMessage?token=USER_TOKEN&channel=CHANNEL_ID&text=hello%20world>`. (Naturally, you can also set the bot's name and image, etc.)
This...is quite interesting. Is there a way to see which user posted the message?
<@U0AQ8GPGR>: Getting a proper response together for you. But the tl;dr is that there is no way to see which user posted the message, it appears.
<@U0D7LHNTX> Thanks! So far it seems to be a way to prank people, but I think the potential for abuse is pretty obvious :innocent:
All bot-messages always have `(BOT)` after the purported name, right?
Used to just be if there was a risk of confusion, but to solve the homoglyph attack problem, Slack switched to _always_ putting `(BOT)` in there.
Yeah, but, say you really dislike a colleague. You can easily post a harassing message as a "bot" with no repercussion.
Basically, if you use your personal user token, you can hit `chat.postMessage` more or less anonymously.
This is a known issue, but we're still thinking of the right way to handle it.

Right, so not hiding that it is a bot, just the audit trail. Seems like clicking on the bot name should open a profile window, instead of taking you to the bot integration, and the bot profile window should include a link through to the `/services/HEX` page which is linked to now, and provide some extra details, such as which user's auth-token was used when a personal token was used.

Still, that just closes one path. Things like Slackbot will post messages on behalf of users, if hit with the API, so the profile window would need to allow the bot to decorate with additional fields (clearly delimited as untrusted, provided by the bot) so that the bot could report whatever else it wants as part of the profile view for that message.

Well, the thing is, the user is identified by their token. It's a user token, not a bot token, so it wasn't actually posted by a bot user…even if it was posted programmatically by a piece of software. Make sense?

<@U0D7LHNTX> Maybe make it possible for admins to see a log of such calls?
Also, <@U0GTXH4JX>, you actually can't click the bot's name.
I'm not at my computer right now, so I can't really demonstrate it.
Strange. I switched tabs (native Mac client) to a Team where I have a bot I wrote, `uuidbot`, clicked the name, and a browser was opened pointing to the `/services/HEX` page for the bot ...
Ah, it's just the incoming webhook configuration. But yes, you can click on the bot's name, for webhook-based messages.
That's what I checked to see what was done instead of a user profile, before making my suggestion.

So, the official answer is: No. Right now these tokens are offered to users specifically for building non-bot integrations (and for API testing!). For which the `as_user` flag is _also_ useful, so you can set a custom name and avatar and all that good stuff. So all these things have their proper place. And it seems to be that abuse is in the nature of the beast :disappointed: Nevertheless, these concerns are something we are discussing now, thanks to you :smile:
<@U0D7LHNTX>, FYI, I've seen some people in the wild doing integrations by asking users to generate a token at <https://api.slack.com/web#authentication> and pasting it in their website
rather than using OAuth flows

Thanks <@U0D7LHNTX> !

<@U0CS6NSF5>: That used to be the _only_ way :smile: That mechanism is now definitely deprecated (but there isn't much we can do about it except say “hey stop that”). I am happy to reach out to them and say “hey, stop that!”.

<@U0AQ8GPGR>: best way to deal with this is queues and retrying with increased intervals.
Something like "Hey, I was out for a little bit, here's what you missed"
there's a bigger problem with retries and it's bots not having access to the history of the channels they are part of
if there's a problem with Slack and the bot gets disconnected, it's unaware about messages sent while reconnecting

and it cannot check the history to backtrack
<@U0CS6NSF5> Hmm, yeah, I was describing a very particular functionality that relies on input from outside of Slack, seems to be much easier to deal with.
your situation about generating content that has to be posted is sorted out with a queque and retries
since you are using sidekick, sidekick can do retries itself, so you can just raise an error when a message delivery fails and have sidekick try it out

What about saving a time stamp every time your bot hits the API successfully and then searching through the messages posted since then? You could also ping the API every, say, 15-30 minutes if there's no activity, to avoid having to search through too many messages?

> What about saving a time stamp every time your bot hits the API successfully and then searching through the messages posted since then? You could also ping the API every, say, 15-30 minutes if there's no activity, to avoid having to search through too many messages? a bot cannot do that since `bot` scope doesn't have access to the `channels.history` endpoint
so you are out of luck with a bot looking for unprocessed messages

> Hmm, maybe Slack could notify users if they're trying to message a bot user or use a slash command while the API is down, similar to the "your message was not sent, retry?" message mobile app shows when you're offline? One of the main benefits of Adaptive inputs like you're describing with Magic Words is their accessibility & discoverability. You can explore a bit by trying them out to see what sorts of data is expected from you and even see a preview of how that might change state in the app. What artifact is created? How will people see it if I go forward with creating it? What types of information fit the expected structure of the command?
It encourages experimentation safely, before it becomes a social artifact.

========================== Announcement ========================== Thanks to Slack, we have an awesome Slack development hangout here. We think that this Slack can become a hub for building :robot_face:s, testing :robot_face:s, showing off :robot_face:s, and much more. This is going to be a lot of fun, let's just make sure that we do it in a respectful manner.
*Rules for installing bots in dev4slack* (1) Create a channel for your bot to live in called #app-[name of your bot] (2) Make sure your bot is only in #app-[name of your bot], unless it really belongs somewhere else and can provide use. Any bot that is at all annoying or distracting will be immediately _/kicked_ out of channels other than #app-[name of your bot]. (3) Your bot should only message members of #app-[name of your bot] and folks who message the bot directly. Bots that send unsolicited messages will be removed. (4) Your bot should not store, extract or display any information from dev4slack on any external website, unless for purposes of demonstrating some other functionality. That is, you may not use a bot for the purpose of reposting or republishing content from dev4slack. In addition, your bot may not collect information about the users of dev4slack, and may not send messages to users (via email, for example) outside of Slack for any reason except for the purposes of demonstrating functionality and with explicit permission from the users being messaged. (5) The moderators of dev4slack reserve the right to remove any integration. (6) Violation of these rules will result in either (a) your bot being removed from dev4slack (b) _you_ being removed from dev4slack, depending on the size of the violation and whether it was intentional. (7) Please +:+1: this post to confirm that you've read it in full before adding any bots. Your +:+1: signifies that you have understood and agree to follow these rules. =================================================================

Hey folks, anyone able to share any cool tips/tricks/insights for Slack/messaging design/development? Am interested in seeing how else can Slack be extended. Here's what I got.. <https://talkhq.com/reply/IhFxdg8mO098FIHa4PiDq4YpLTh3cJD6yUfUcmlOSpf1|reply>

> *Each message is a flexible / updatable panel* you can automatically insert 'something' upon submission (eg. chat.update upon matching trigger). This allows random actions to be attached to the message. Updates can be externally triggered. eg. It doesn't have to be based on the message but something else can update the panel. image switching (haven't tried this yet..but from api seems feasible). Images can then represent more complex/ provide higher density information .. ex. stock chart that periodically updates, counters, etc. Eg. This goes around the limitations of layout/etc that is present in slack. <https://talkhq.com/reply/IhFxdg8mO098FIHa4PiDq4Y4r9BMHRHsYrZ-TYYPBsSq|reply>

>*Reactions can substitute for counters / triggers* ex. individual reaction can represent different votes. (the only problem being that you need at least 1 to kick start a reaction on a message). Conceptually, something like <http://doodle.com|doodle.com> can be implemented in-situ in slack (combined with the above that is.. eg. allowing for the table based layout) <https://talkhq.com/reply/IhFxdg8mO098FIHa4PiDq4YCb3r4Mmaxad6mUfVPakE2|reply>

>*JS injection allows for interface experiments* if you want to try something else out on the interface, it isn't normally possible. BUT, with JS injection (whether by bookmarklet or via a browser plugin you can munge mess about with the web client. Then if you want it to work as an app on mac/pc, encapsulating the browser should work (eg. electron For instance, at the moment you can't add additional actions to the action bar, but if you have control over the client side (eg. tell everyone to use a browser on a laptop), *you can add your own custom actions to the action bar* <https://talkhq.com/reply/IhFxdg8mO098FIHa4PiDq4YiVUJ0bCwsZKF6_TjGyJ41|reply>
so… something like this <https://talkhq.com/images/webapp.png> <https://talkhq.com/reply/IhFxdg8mO098FIHa4PiDq4X5x1Kram2sr_pzB35Jfk2M|reply>
interesting...
also talkhq itself is great hacking <@U0CS7U85R>++
:grin: <https://talkhq.com/reply/IhFxdg8mO098FIHa4PiDq4ZmxvXtVc-4VI0rkMhLJRTL|reply>
do you add the reply => talkhq links by hand ? That's a bit invading :simple_smile:

<@U0HBN0L9M|matthieu>: that's automatic and only if you're registered. For a team (not a social board like this), it works out since everyone is either 'in'... or 'out'. Basically threading can't work (*accurately) unless there is a way to tag the parent message. Conceptually, that will be also how you can add actions. For instance, if you were running a news org and need an additional trigger to post something to twitter (from slack).
*accurately: there's other ways of course (time bounding / loose categorization / @replies linking / post message manual work / etc) but not enough time to build it :smile: <http://talkhq.com/reply/IhFxdg8mO098FIHa4PiDq4ZkXbnhmv2O4tqDptaOYABl|reply> in <http://talkhq.com/view/IhFxdg8mO098FIHa4PiDq4ZkXbnhmv2O4tqDptaOYABl|thread>
but that's added because you go through your own browser addon ?

<@U0HBN0L9M>: it's via rtm + chat.update web api and doesn't require the browser plugin. Basically a server process detects if a registered user posted 'something' and then instantly adds the reply link... (and also updates the original thread with the reply count)

in a way, it's like smooz (pretty cool btw), where instead of crossposting to a different team upon detecting the match, it just updates the original message. <http://talkhq.com/reply/ID9CmBWYJt3X-kedIKH1dJm14aKpXcRTuAR0NF_LW6ydL_qXyV50K-85DD-qKVz9U|reply> in <http://talkhq.com/view/IhFxdg8mO098FIHa4PiDq4ZvgpVnNIob-aHAFtRlwBD_|thread>

Hi everyone, I´m Mariano from Argentina, this is my first message. (Sorry for my English, I speak Spanish). I was reading this channel for a while and I think there are three main topics around Bots: Artificial Intelligence, Automation and Bot skills. I explain myself: - AI it's about a bot interacting, understanding and learning from humans. (NLP, Conversation carryng, Machine learning, Understanding context) - Automation it's about a bot automating things using external tools. (Ex: Deploying, Moving cards in Trello, Getting alerts from a monitoring system) - Bot skills it's about all the things that a bot can do to improve human teams (Remember things, Arrange a meeting, Do funny things) I'd like some opinions about this.
Hmm, another thought: designing bots is quite a bit like designing NPCs in video games. Time to look at some game development resources :simple_smile:
:smile:

Does anyone know if the user_id for a given slacker remains the same across teams? I know my image doesn't persist across teams.
I thought they were unique to the team
:point_up: that's correct. user ids are unique across teams.
<@U04S1QCPC>, unique across teams or per team?
every slack user has a unique id. if you are on team A with email address Z and team B with email address Z, you will have a unique id for each of A and B.
<@U04S1QCPC>, so a user is going to have a different ID in each team rather than a unique one across teams
right.
<@U04S1QCPC>, and two users from different teams can have the same ID, can't they?
nope, they shouldn't be able to.
shouldn't be or must be unique across teams?
username could be the same, but user_id is randomly generated at time of user creation, no?
is there a constraint for uniqueness across teams? I was told there isn't
I asked a long time ago and was told that collisions of user IDs across teams was possible
the information might be wrong, though, it wouldn't be the first time :simple_smile:
ew
I'd hope that the user ID was "salted" with the name of the team
the user IDs will be unique across teams but we recommend always storing them alongside team ID.
:ok_hand: that's a different answer to the one I got in the past :simple_smile:
much safer for people developing integrations, though, so happy it's that way instead

ok – i verified my statement with our backend team and have an addendum: user IDs are globally unique _currently_ but that may change in the future, which is why we haven't documented that as an assumption that should be made. so, the team_id:user_id pairing should be your go-to.

<@U04S1QCPC>, you should make that very clear, otherwise integrations might start assuming user IDs are globally unique which could lead to leaked private data from 3rd party integrations if there's an UID collision across two teams using the same integration
*make that very clear and prominent in the docs, I mean
we should document that better, i agree.
also, notifying current developers
I would guess there's already some apps in the gallery assuming user ids to be globally unique
Good topic to clarify, thanks <@U04S1QCPC> <@U0CS6NSF5>!
happy to help :simple_smile:
<@U04S1QCPC> clean answer
26^6 is « only » 300M users, so better not limit your ambition right
36^6, since it includes numbers too
62^6 as long as they make them case-sensitive
:simple_smile:

<@U0HKDKHD4>, for that you will need your own user profile with a unique ID and allow the user to link their Slack accounts to your account
and in your profile, do not use email as the id, since you'll probably want to allow them to change the email too :simple_smile:
we designed everything around team_id + user_id just to handle the use case of same user different team, guess it future proofs things if user_id someday isn't unique :simple_smile:

I maintain an IRC bot - pmxbot. Our company has used this bot on freenode and our own internal server for years. We now use Slack, and while the bot run on slack via the IRC gateway, I imagine it would see a much greater adoption if it ran on Slack natively. To that end, I've created this ticket with the project (<https://github.com/yougov/pmxbot/issues/43>). Anyone interested in adapting pmxbot to run on Slack, please feel free to ping me here or reach out on Github.

Just started seeing a new message subtype this morning, "reconnect_url" - can't find it in the slack API docs, bot is still connected and working just fine. Anyone know why I'd be getting that?
yeah
me too!!
<@U07VCKRUK> any info?
Yea def not listed here <https://api.slack.com/events/message>
as a message subtype?
no as the main type field
yep
they have been testing it for a while
it's a WS connection you can use to reconnect quickly in case of disconnection, without calling `rtm.start`
AFAIK it's used by the native clients
but it's still under development and undocummented
and there's the big question about whether you can loose messages or get them twice
when you call `rtm.start` you have a state dump and can treat the WS connection as an oplog to keep your state in sync with Slack to certain extent
I don't know how `reconnect_url` will fit in there :simple_smile:
Sounds like they're addressing slack's terrible behaviour on slow internet connections. yay!
<@U0J283T6E>: yep, my understanding is that the feature is to deal with flaky internet connections

which makes sense, since current reconnect via 2G/3G is painful since reconnecting right now takes 2 requests (`rtm.start` and the WS) and the `rtm.start` reply can be huge for a flaky connection :simple_smile:
with all this being said, as usual: there's lots of undocummented events/fields/web api methods. *Just rely on documented features*
Yea, I only just started seeing that about an hour ago and was just wondering what it was.
<@U0CS6NSF5>: sound advice :simple_smile:
<@U0K7Y2SK0>: I've been seeing it since mid-december :simple_smile:
weird.
they've probably been releasing it progressively

i probably wouldn't couple your monitoring into slack too tightly - (only use slack as a messaging end point) -
Slack is not the destination for these alerts, it's the source. "Is Slack Up? Yes/No" is all I'm after
but in a way that means I don't have to scrape <http://status.slack.com|status.slack.com> looking for a specific image (or worse, a specific CSS Class!)

As an example, the following works well for Github: ```#### github.py # # Monitors the Github Status Api and # reports back on platform availability. # # (c) DevopsGuys Ltd/Matthew Macdonald-Wallace 2016 # # Made available under the MIT license
import json import requests import sys
status_uri = '<https://status.github.com/api/status.json>' r = requests.get(status_uri) gh_status = json.loads(r.text) if gh_status['status'] == "major": exit_code = 2 elif gh_status['status'] == "minor": exit_code = 1 elif gh_status['status'] == "good": exit_code = 0 else: exit_code = 3
print "Current github status is %s" % gh_status['status'] sys.exit(exit_code) ```

<https://www.producthunt.com/tech/kifi-for-slack#comment-225966>
<@U0K176R8A>, depends on what you need
`auth.test` already gives you the username, UID and Team ID
yep but that's not enough
We use that API for login / signup, meaning we want to create a Kifi profile from a user's Slack profile (minimally name, picture, email address)
I don't think people are scared of giving their own information to us, but it gets scary when to do that they have to give away their entire team
you could ask the user for the email address and avatar yourselves
Sure but that defeats the point of using Slack for easy sign up / login
It seems weird to me that to get the personal information of a user that explicitly gave permissions you have no way around asking that same information for each and every member
not really, you can skip asking for a password and just need to ask for it twice
many services doing sign in/up using OAuth ask for the email themselves
I'd love an API that returns the same information as `<http://users.info|users.info>`, just for the user owning the token you're calling it with.
you can test wether skipping the email request helps with sign up conversions
if you don't have account recovery via email you don't even need to confirm the emails to provide the service
and you can always offer a 2-click “get the details from Slack” option

They do, and to some extent we do to when we don't get one (from Facebook, Twitter or Slack) but the optimal flow should aim for the simplest most enjoyable onboarding experience.
Both Twitter and Facebook have different APIs depending on how far you want to reach in their graph: on the one hand APIs to fetch first-degree info about the user / node that explicitly gave authorization vs on the other hand APIs requiring a stronger set of permissions to fetch second-degree info (about your friends, who didn't give explicit authorization in that context).

Is there a reason to prefer @bot commands or slash commands? Asking for a friend.

<@U0KRESR89>: the problem with @bot commands is that you need to invite the bot to the channel and you can technically "listen" to the conversation, so the team/org has to be comfortable with you doing that .. with a / command the integration is less intrusive and is available right away
IMO

it depends on what problem you are trying to solve. / commands are great for one-off actions, while bots are more for prolonged engagement. Since bots can be ambient listeners, they can at some point proactively engage with you / notify you
syntax is also different when interacting. / commands are really like command-line interfaces: [executable] [flag1|value1] [flagN|valueN]

interacting with bots is having to parse sentences / natural language. of course, you could always look for literal sentences like “what is my name”, but it also leaves it up for interpretation. kind of getting in the smart assistant, language processing, AI business.
<@U0CSBGTKM>: In reference to <https://dev4slack.slack.com/archives/general/p1454565482000595>, how were you able to rename a disabled bot user? I don't see that option
It might be because I am not the team admin...
<@U0KRESR89>: very fundamental question.

I wrote this ``` There are basically three main types of Slack apps, which roughly fall into three buckets
- Incoming webhooks are for notifications (outside -> inside), - commands are for simple actions (inside -> outside), - and bots for two-sided interactions and conversational interfaces.
Of course one could use bots for notifications, or as a “super-command”, but they thrive in complex situations where they can either extract better context or provide richer informations through conversations. ```
<https://medium.com/@MVaragnat/how-to-build-a-slack-app-5b83d71e083a#.l6dgzclv7>
If the interaction is limited, then go for a command app, it's simpler, available in all channels, does not require scary permissions

<@U0HNAA1GU>: ok, if you have 100 clients, with 100 bots, then they need to run all the time.
Yes. I am basically sending all incoming messages towards a seperate service that I can scale up if need be
I'm curious to know other approaches though
do you use a bot or slash command?
I am asking cause a slash command is _kind of simple_ cause it is like building an API. I only receives a request. But bots are connected all the time to slack and have to listen.
A bot
<@U0LCT5LAY>: best practices would basically depend on what you need
as you mention, it's not as easy as just adding more processes, since you'll have to maintain all the connections up and running

simplest option is to use consistent hashing to split connections across different processes, but depending on your requirements that would be just enough or you'll need some extra work :simple_smile:

<@U0LCT5LAY>: I'd caution against slash command because they can be hard to discover. But this is also understanding your audience. If we're talking general audience that's not experienced with scripts, start with @ mentions, then teach /'s through conversation
If you use howdy, try it's “build a meeting” conversational experience. Does a great job of teaching proper syntax
<@U0J27NX0X>: `/commands` which reply in public are not too bad with discoverability
see giphy as an example, I believe was (is?) the most used integration, and it's a slash command
oh totally. I guess I see giphy a bit different because it doesn't feel so narrow? Which is weird since it just does gifs. In some ways, it feels bot like since there really isn't much of a syntax.
I'm thinking more of commands like `/remind` which have a mildly complicated syntax, are not used that often, and require a bit more knowledge of a platform's capabilities
yep, that's no luck with discoverability
but the same happens with bots that are primarily used via DMs
in that sense, the help with discoverability comes from using the bots in public
or being checked in on?
anyways, yes, you're totally right. Very public /'s could totally work. Hopefully slack and Peach will educate the world. People figured out #'s somehow, right?

and just interjecting

Asynchronous is great but we found in our testing that we had a lot more incomplete standups with that model.

Good morning everyone! Anyone knows if there's an actual max length on channel names? Doc says 21 characters for user created channels, but in practice MPDMs have just blown up our DB column :)
<@U0K176R8A>: MPDMs are special beast
they certainly are
they don't have an actual name, but the name is based on the nicks of the connected users, so it doesn't follow the name limits
Still, Slack APIs (e.g.incoming webhooks) return us with one and it blows up. Any higher known internal limit somewhere? <@U0D7LHNTX>
<@U0K176R8A>: sounds like it, but that's your app
you might have setup the “channel name” (however you called it) column with a 21 character limit

Of course I have, according to the doc. Now I'm merely asking if there's any known value I should bump it up to or whether we should start detecting when our users pick MPIM channels and have special logic to handle them.
<@U0K176R8A>: what DB are you using?
He's asking if _Slack_ has an upper bound we can count on, since the documented 21 char limit doesn't apply to MPDMs
<@U0L15UHQV>: I know, but if they are using postgress they can just set the column to TEXT which has variable unlimited lenght
As far as I know—there is no upper bound.
and in postgres there's no performance hit in using TEXT vs VARCHAR
and whatever the current limit is, it might change in the future
You should anticipate that those names will blow up, unfortunately.

in general, I would expect changes like names getting longer, user IDs not being unique across teams, receiving undocumented events via the RTM API (already happens), receiving undocumented fields within RTM events (this happens too), etc.
<@U0CS6NSF5>: user IDs are different from team to team ?
Late reply but thanks for the responses <@U0CS6NSF5> and <@U0LPETY3F>.
<@U0JPS3SHX>: right now IDs are unique across teams, but it's recommended to always store users based on their user and team ID

it's just this - can attachement text be formatted ? Docs says no for title, yes for text. Reality seems to say no, all the time
damn reality
<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T8mtiFg9mG8>
The answer is: No for title, yes for text IF YOU SET `mrkdwn_in` to be `[“text”]`
>>> Valid values for mrkdwn_in are: ["pretext", "text", "fields"]. Setting "fields" will enable markup formatting for the value of each field.
Not super intuitive
<@U0HH00DS7>: To use markdown in attachment, you need to tell slack you're doing it using `{'mrkdwn_in' : ['text'] }`

<https://api.slack.com/docs/formatting#message_formatting>
> By default bot message text will be formatted, but attachments are not. To disable formatting on a non-user message, set the mrkdwn property to false. To enable formatting on attachment fields, set the mrkdwn_in array on each attachment to the list of fields to process.
thanks

the examples dont seem to work for me…

This message contains a URL <http://foo.com/>
So does this one: <http://www.foo.com|www.foo.com>

By default, messages you pass to API methods and webhooks will be assumed to be pre-formatted based on the above spec. That is, you can include marked up URLs, user links, channel links and commands, but we will still linkify any non-linked URLs present in your message.
sending from the server they dont get linkified. maybe have to be in an attachment and `markdown`' flagged ?
oh, because botkit is using the RTM api by default…
I used attachments + markdown.
with bot.reply?

The RTM API only supports posting simple messages formatted using our default message formatting mode. It does not support attachments or other message formatting modes. To post a more complex message as a user clients can call the chat.postMessage Web API method with as_user set to true.

the way I do it:
i guess i should be able to see the user that reacted and realize that's me

chat.postMessage -> callback, get ts -> add reaction 1 to ts -> callback, add reaction 2 to ts (etc...) -> callback, add listener to reaction_added -> if reaction.item.ts matches message.ts, then it's a user clicking on your reactions
there may be less convoluted ways to do it
less callback-hellish

<@U0MUZB415>: If you want to DM a user though, you would need at least an optional perspective like `chat:write:bot`.
<@U0KPRUYVD>: Thanks! But is the answer ‘yes' to my other question?
can I just create an application with a set of scopes and act as a bot without having a bot permission? (besides being listed in user list)?

<@U0MUZB415>: The answer in general is yes, you're allowed to mix and match scopes. But If you don't ask for a `bot` scope, your app would be calling methods on behalf of the user who authed it, not a bot user.
You could still make this work by using just a few API methods (as you suggest) + an `incoming webhook` Slack app scope
bear in mind though that the `incoming webhook` scope would post to the user's Slackbot, it won't open a DM on behalf of a bot user
does that make sense?
Yes, that's very helpful. So if I use the application scope, it will always be on behalf of the auth-ed user (the user who originally authenticated)
In practice, I don't see that preventing me from doing anything
besides the direct DM

Is there an update process?
Will depend on your deployment. If you're building a bot out where you're going to be hosting and running all the servers, then yes you will be able to silently update.
If you allow your clients/users to manage their own deployments, or they fork off or whatever, then they'll have to pull your new version or update manually
If you're going to be increasing oAuth scopes with the addition of new slash commands, then you're going to have to have something set up to re-auth

Can a bot respond to a Slash command? And if so, what happens when a user uses a slash command in a channel where Bot is not present?
Slash commands do not appear in chat, so *technically* no, in the way that bots 'overhear' and respond
BUT slash commands can trigger a response via RTM or API in whatever code they execute
So yes
Yes bots can respond
Any service can use the chat.postMessage web API to post messages
But a bot will not be able to RTM into a channel he is not in
Soooo... yes and no?
Ha, yeah
so if someone uses a Slash command and there is a bot connected to the app, will the Avatar responding be the bot?
...if you tell it to be. When using the chat.postMessage, you can specify what username and avatar on a per-message basis
Hm, so if I'll use the bot's username to respond to a chat command and that bot is not in that channel, will it show up?
Yes.
Seriously?
:simple_smile:
Yes.
The RTM connection from the bot and the Web API you can use to respond to a slash command are 2 different things
And you will confuse the hell out of your users
If your bot also does RTM
Becaues they will think the bot is broken by not being in the channel
So if they see it post and try to use it
Hah
And what's the username / avatar that's used if it's not a bot?
And the Web API chat.postMessage has the ability to choose whatever nickname / avatar (it's up to you to use the same one as your bot)
Whatever you want it to be.
I thought a slash command just hits an endpoint
Yes.
And so does chat.postMessage
You asked if a bot could respond, and the answer is "kinda"
You can make a script that responds and *looks* just like the RTM bot
But it's not the RTM connected bot account, it's just a script that gets triggered on an endpoint and posts *as* the bot from the web api
You could have it post as *anyone*
Or a non-user

<@U07M21QKS> YES
if i understand your question correctly this is exactly what we did.

won't apply to everyone, but we went one step further, I was faced with the typical question of ‘time to build the native apps' as we had a great webapp and everything was working well on the backend and although we had a mobile H5 version we wanted alerts and other things as well as to be in the ‘store'…but as a startup I have to make hard resource decisions…I did something a little crazy, I punted on the mobile apps and went 100% towards Slack as a platform. Risky, but turned out to be the best move for us. We made it into the App Directory when it launched (even got invited to the launch party) and we have lots of organic growth via slack users. I also don't have to support iOS and Android platforms, stores etc. as Slack does it for me.
that makes so much sense for a use case like market.space
if you hadn't focused on slack first, ppl would have asked you at least a notification itnegration anyway

yes, not for everyone but going ‘headless' is really cool and for the first time ever…I don't ‘have' to have mobile apps. Without Slack I would have had to do this…in 2011 I had no choice (wth my last company, PrivacyChoice). Times are changing :simple_smile:

Type `/find —help` to see more

<@U0J283T6E>: -help doesn't work for me...
<@U0J283T6E>: neither does “help"
there's a double dash in there - unix convention which the slack client reformats to a unicode _emdash_. ```/find - - help /find —help```
<@U0554MQJB>: I just tried and it works for me, any joy for you?

thanks mate!

You can use `/find —feedback` to send comments to us anonymously

really cool app though
congrats
it's a double dash, not a single one
<@U0J283T6E>'s autocorrect was turning - - into a long dash, the same way three consecutive dots are turned into an ellipsis
they should set `/find` to return the help, instead of searching for nothing, and remove the `/find --help`

Hey guys, I have a problem with my bot deployed on Heroku. Would any of you know how to solve this problem?
Using BotKit, this is my code for my bot to shutdown.
So when I ran "sudo shutdown", my bot shutdown. How can I reinitiate it properly?
I went to my Heroku site and it said Application Error. And what appears in the logs is:
Would anybody be able to help me? Thanks!
<@U0L4DR2V7>: you app is crashing, you need to figure out why
oh, you added a command to crash the app :confused:
that's why, you are stopping the dyno
Oh. Is there anyway to reinitiate it through Slack?
Thanks for the response also, <@U0CS6NSF5>!
you should restart the heroku dyno using their API instead of crashing the bot
Oh, okay. I'll check that out. But is there anyway that I can shutdown my bot from Slack and turn it back on?
i think what you want to do, it terminate the RTM connection
you can use heroku's api from your bot to restart/stop your app, you won't be able to start it, obviously, since your bot will be stopped
not shut down the whole process
Oh, okay. Thanks <@U0CS6NSF5>. I'll check out the Slack API.
<@U0HBN0L9M>: Is there anyway to terminate the RTM connection with a command that I can type on Slack?
<@U0L4DR2V7>: if what you want is to stop the RTM connection you'll have to disconnect, rather than stop you process (which is what you were doing)
none of those things will be with the Slack API
Mhm, what command can I run to do that? Is there any?
instead of process.exit(), try bot.closeRTM()
disconnecting the RTM connection will be with botkit's API, restarting the heroku process will be with heroku's API
Oh. If I perform that <@U0HH00DS7>, will I be able to reinitiate my bot from Slack?
<@U0CS6NSF5>: Oh. Okay. Thanks for the help!
np
not sure what means "from slack"
from the bot - no - because it would be disconnected
from your app - yes - with bot.startRTM()
<@U0HBN0L9M>: he could reinitiate it with a slash command
from slack

hey folks, you probably saw our onboarding bot featured in Chat Bots weekly last week. Now we've released the JS framework we used to build it:
<http://blog.smooch.io/how-to-build-your-own-smooch-bot/>
it uses Smooch to connect to a bunch of different user-facing channels (Facebook, SMS, iOS, Android, Web, etc….) and back end channels (Slack, HipChat, Zendesk,etc…)

we started on BotKit and then had to take a step back and build our own framework so that we could handle the scale of requests our platform sees (it was hard to run BotKit in a node cluster across multiple servers due to difficulties in data persistence)
Take a look at our post and feel free to shoot me any questions!

Hi, Is there anyone who is familiar with howdy botkit? I am using that as the base code to develop an application as I am new to slack. I have a requirement to keep the bot online 24*7. I am noticing a behavior, the bot goes offline even when the script is still running with no console messages being logged about the failure. I have tried running the script in background to make sure that the connection is persistent. Even with that the bot was up only for two hours and went down on its own. Could anyone please suggest something on this issue.
it might be related to Slack websocket disconnect we've been experiencing sometimes, where we have to restart the server on websocket disconnect, not sure since we don't use botkit
<https://github.com/slackhq/node-slack-client/issues/53>
ok. So, could you please guide me with the right way to achieve this functionality in other cases where we can make the bot be online all the time.

this is not best practice as covered in that github conversation, but we wait for a websocket `close` event and restart the server. the next step for this will be to just re-connect just the slack team related to the websocket `close` event to avoid server restart
I did not understand the second part of your reply. Could you please clarify.

in this example event: `slackUsers[user.team_id].on('close', function(res) { })` we restart the server now, but we will eventually link the `user.team_id` to the `close` event and just `open` a new socket for that specific team

is there a way to get the name of the user who authenticated / added your bot to Slack? i saw that adding calls to Slack does this, when they first message just you on the team
<@U0RDALRU0>: You can get the name if you use a `user:read` scope when you authenticate. It will come back in a `user_info` node on the json
thank you <@U0AFABJAJ> !
np
<@U0RDALRU0>: do you want the full name or the nick name?
the nick name and user id you can get from `auth.test` with the `identify` scope
Yes. If you don't have `users:read`, the name will be nil in `info` node…the tradeoff is that your app has to ask for an additional scope

<@U0AFABJAJ>: if they are provisioning a `bot`, the bot already has `users:read` though, so no need for that scope in the user token, they can just check the details based on the user id from `auth.test` with the user token and check the user details with the bot token
<@U0CS6NSF5>: Yes…I did not know that is what you were trying to get at :+1:
depends on the details they need and the scopes they are currently asking for, just mentioning other ways :simple_smile:
they might not need any extra scopes from what they already have
Yeah…if you wanted email for example, you would have to use `users:read` though, correct?
<@U0AFABJAJ>: not if you have a bot access token
since `bot` includes `users:read` already
Oh! Awesome….I did not know that…I though `auth.test` was limiting
Thanks <@U0CS6NSF5>

Hello Friends. I am developing a payments app for Slack, which requires authenticating the user (validating the user credentials against backend) every time a transaction is done via slack. I am trying to figure out what is the best way to authenticate. Asking the user to include password as slash command argument is not a good idea because it is typed in the an open text field (password not hidden as you type). Do you have any suggestion regarding how to handle passwords in slack apps?
(That would also be a violation of the Slack TOS!)

I have a couple of thoughts on this. The first is that you can use Slack as a source of authentication in itself. (The OAuth flow is pretty suitable as an authentication mechanism as-is. Improvements to this mechanism are in the works!)
But you probably also want authorization. This can be…for now…accomplished by providing a link for the user to click on.
I'd be happy to talk more about this over DM!
or do 2-factor auth: send an SMS with details of the transaction and a one-time code to be entered via slash commands
the OAuth flow has it's drawbacks: you cannot force to identify a user in particular, and the user might be already authenticated in the browser which would get around any auth
I would probably go with 2-factor auth (authentication+authorization) or a link requiring authentication and authorization
Stripe checkout does SMS confirmation when saving the CC details too, if I remember correctly, rather than relying on passwords

``` Post to an IM channel Posting to an IM channel is a little more complex depending on the value of as_user.
If as_user is false: - Pass a username (<@U0GNZCZ71>) as the value of channel to post to that user's <@USLACKBOT> channel as the bot. - Pass the IM channel's ID (D023BB3L2) as the value of channel to post to that IM channel as the bot. The IM channel's ID can be retrieved through the im.list API method.
If as_user is true: - Pass the IM channel's ID (D023BB3L2) as the value of channel to post to that IM channel as the authenticated user. The IM channel's ID can be retrieved through the im.list API method. ```

We want to tie some web-based onboarding into our oauth 2) having never released a slack bot, and not really knowing the scale constraints of BotKit and node generally, at what point do you think something like BeepBoop becomes necessary?

welcome!
agreed on the onboarding point!

<@U0K7V5M43>: 1) interesting use case, it wouldn't be hard for us to create an API to facilitate this now. We've been focused on trying to make everything as turn-key as possible. One thing that did change today is that you can link straight into the oauth flow so if you want to manage the flow up until the Slack oauth dance... For example: <https://beepboophq.com/api/slack/auth/add-to-slack/8a54caf3d109400fa8581744e7d96e9d>
2) our goal is to make you not have to think when scaling becomes necessary, whether 1 team or 1000's. It's definitely stuff you can do yourself, you just have to do it yourself :simple_smile:

ok neat, so yeah I do think owning the slack redirect URI is important to us. We do things like let a user pick the channel to add the bot to via a select input. The scaling aspect, we're getting ready to run a beta, and just really have no clue how things are going to go at this point. So I guess we run the beta and find out!
