BONUS IDEA: :bulb: Amazon Team Gifting Slackbot: A Slackbot where you can register by creating a profile with your address (private) which can have items purchased from Amazon sent to you via other Slack group members.. To clarify: [slash]gift @username Would bring up a link to Amazon where you can browse items to gift @username and all of @username's info will be preset into the recipients address info whence you're done selecting the gift.. I do not know if this is technically viable.. but it would sure be cool if it was!
If there exists a birthday notification Slackbot this would work perfectly with said bot.. & of course holidays would be very fun!
Idk if Slack would be interested in charging commission on Slack facilitated sales but there may be an opportunity for this.

Anyways this idea is also free for use for anyone here! Please notify me if you do use it and you deem it appropriate for me to use "participation in development" of this on my resume :simple_smile: & of course please notify me if there is anyway I can help develop this as I would love to upgrade my tech knowledge.
<@U0LLUCLP3>: re: /gift - Amazon has wishlists. You could just have /gift return the user's preferred wishlist URL.
/giphy entrepreneurs
^ seems legit.
:heart: Paris Hilton. Would love to have her as a mentor.
<@U0U9DQ4TH> I am aware of wish lists, however I overlooked this during consideration.. Thanks for bringing it up.. It really makes this so much better/viable!

I was asked.. but what NEED does it address? I replied.. Amazon may see an increase in sales.. and Slack may charge a commission on sales facilitated.. I think to sum up the NEED addressed is the need for gift giving in interpersonal relationships.. Which has existed forever. Thanks.

I hate the term but I'm mostly an "idea person".. but I have no idea how dev or monetize this.. I would love to see it come to fruition though.. I may even /gift a certain dev who implements :simple_smile:
<http://www.justinscarpetti.com/projects/amazon-wish-lister/> <https://github.com/doitlikejustin/amazon-wish-lister>
monetizing it could be easy. instead of simply linking a user to the person's amazon wishlist url
^ you do that, you fetch the wishlist data, and build your own bespoke URLs with your amazon affiliate ID in the link to individual product items
then, if the person clicks through and buys, you get paid as an affiliate. kinda skeezy, but money is money
the problem with gift giving: those people who already give gifts, already do. those who don't... won't start if you just give them yet another means to spend money to buy a gift for someone
the problem to solve is: how do you change someone's core behavior from "one who does not give gifts" to "one who gives gifts"?

I really appreciate your feedback & this will help me tremendously.. so Thank you. To address your concerns.. I feel there is a such a wide array of Slack groups (+growing) that people will gift their co-workers/loved ones/friends appropriately inevitably.
sure, in a large enough population, you'll have people who are gift-givers
but, my point is, those people already are gifting people - they don't need any help

then, there are the rest of us, who despite being given a wishlist full of things, expressed desire for certain items, etc., just can't bring themselves to give a gift - not because they don't want to, but because they just... can't... bring themselves to do it
(I fall into that latter category: it results in lots of problems with my wife, for example.)

the people who are "gifters" can go out and pick out a gift for someone they don't even know and most of the time pick out something that's reasonably appreciated - it's crazy how I've seen people do that
as a kid, I absolutely hated the whole "secret santa" game that everyone loves to play. it would literally cause me to get sick with anxiety.

what you're suggesting to implement, might make it easier for gifters to send gifts but now you have to ask yourself "is this easier or better than what they're already doing to send gifts?" otherwise why would they use it? but, it does nothing for people like me who is a anti-gifter to overcome that obstacle and send a gift... that's the market you grow to really make an impact

:thinking_face: I don't think conversion of non-gift-givers will be an issue as the target demographic is people who are inclined to give gifts.. The people who are inclined to give gifts will find this a convenient manner of doing so (esp. since there in no appropriate alternative to gifting Slack peers) I originally intended for gift givers to be able to gift anything however the wish list consideration triumphed in viability. I think that this will be a great way for Slack members to show appreciation for fellow members contributions to the group.. I personally would love to gift the creator of the main Slack group I hang out in.. & another person that gave me an invite to PH.. People have helped me so much over the course of my "Slack career" and I just want a way to be able to give back.. I hope these reasoning suffice your concerns.. :simple_smile: & Thank you so much for the correspondence it's proved to be very kind and generous.

Right now.. Say I wanted to gift you <@U0U9DQ4TH> for all your helpful feedback :wink: I would have to gain your permissions, and go through a whole process of picking out a gift, and then awkwardly asking for your mailing address (which ruins the surprise & is a privacy issue) unless you already have an Amazon wish list which I could ask and then ask you to provide the link.. which would be an additional hassle.. With this new slackbot you can instantly access everyone's (in Slack) Amazon wish list which is just an added range of the Slack community.

so, I don't know about other people, but I am friends with someone who is a gift-giver. in order to surprise me, he reached out to a mutual friend of ours who had my address, so that he could order a book and have it shipped to me. in my limited experience, those who are gift-givers will find a way.
the premise that reducing the obstacles for gift givers to give gifts will increase the number of gifts they give needs to be thoroughly tested - I suspect the lift will be minimal, like 1-3% maybe

something that always surprised me was the number of incredibly generous people out there who would freely donate (e.g., virtual tip jar) - I always thought "ha, who ever gives money to those things" until I set one of my own up for a mildly successful project I put together... it totally blew my mind
i think there was a /beer thing that let you buy someone a beer as a way of saying thanks - basically facilitated sending someone $5

is there a way/API for a slack app to request a list of all its subscriber auth tokens and webhook urls? (e.g. in the case of catastrophic db loss).. the redis db behind CatFacts suffered hardware failure and heroku provided me a new db, but i don't think any backup of previous db was made :disappointed:
<@U09KR8QR3>: no way to do that
Redis is not a long term database, you should never use it to persist data you really care about
well yes i know.. i'm hoping to reconstruct the data.. slack has it in their dbs somewhere :simple_smile:
tons of companies use Redis, but you still have your data in a proper database
e.g: twitter's timeliens are (or used to be) served from Redis
of course. that's not the question i'm asking tho
but the tweets are stored in a database and then sent to redis
oh, I thought you meant Slack has redis somewhere, :simple_smile:
yes, Slack will have all that data somewhere, but it's not available
via APIs
right.. that's what i'm after
that's not going to be possible
why
I can't think of any OAuth API that allows you to do that
if it was available, compromising the client id and secret from an app would give the attacker access to all the resources from everybody who authorised your app
not possible now, sure, but could be possible if they add it
yeah, but same compromise is already possible by collecting data as ppl auth (more difficult, yes, but vuln exists)
in any event, i'll see if i can bug someone there about it
much more contained
I doubt you will be able to get it, but good luck getting it sorted
and whatever you do, start storing your data in a proper DB :simple_smile:
a "proper DB" would not have withstood a hardware failure either.. the prob is i had no backups... redis has persistence
i take your point, but my db choice wasn't the issue here
Is heroku a safe provider? It's not the first time I hear stories (it's still your fault if you don't have a backup though)
<@U0GT29N3A>: they are safe, but you have to pay to be safe
e.g: heroku-redis free is without High Availability and without persistence
heroku-postgress free retains just a couple of backups and lacks HA too
running postgres with HA with them starts at $200/month
<@U09KR8QR3>: when talking about proper DB I implicitly include doing backups :simple_smile:
I think heroku postgres free could be setup with daily backups for the last 7 days + 2 manual backups
heroku postgress could be setup with automatic, free backups
and heroku mongolab allows backup for 50c$
I'm trying to write a bot that responds with an image, kind of like giphy does. Is there a way to do that with Botkit?
Anyone know a simple fix for this issue? Should it be fixed in botkit or the middleware? <https://github.com/howdyai/botkit/issues/175>

<@U0ZD1NCUD>: an easy way would be to simply include a url to the image you want to show. Slack will unfurl it for you (<https://api.slack.com/docs/unfurling>). The way that I'm assuming giphy does is is via the attachments of a message (<https://api.slack.com/docs/attachments>) more specifically the `image_url`. These features are available via any message you send with Botkit.
<@U0Y32KTV1>: Thanks! That's exactly how I ended up doing it <https://github.com/raysarebest/xkcd-slack/>

I'm seeing all the Facebook new bots going through a rigid process. Like instead of "show me $10 men tshirts" it takes you through the details one by one: What are you shopping for [men/women] what are you looking for [shoes/shirts/pants] what prices range [under 10/10-100/200+] etc. while it's easier to code and more proof, do you think it's a good experience? It's like filling a form in pieces
it may take even less time that saying `show me $10 men tshirts`
it depends on the case, but filling a form in this way it can be pretty quick
The shopping example is weird. When you shop you want as many pictures as possible and then dig deeper in. I want to see 2000 articles, then filter down one by one.
Not show me three t shirts and then if I want to see more well you're out of luck.
<@U0XTF3HGS>: I think that's where the bots & “ai” really bring something new to the table
because, from experience, I don't buy when I see 2000 items, I just browse endlessly
I buy by narrowing down :simple_smile:
If they can make very strong recommendations that make sense then sure

yeah, I think the oppty is more about having that "personal shopper” experience provided by bots. The website can still serve as the “endless aisle” with 1000s of items, but the bot should help you narrowing it down
But that's some crazy level AI
maybe :smile: I think they can start with something quite simple & still have results though
basically just like the regular vendors in the shops (or the people chatting with you on the website, for websites that have that)
they don't do crazy stuff
they just start with basic questions (type of item, size, color, etc…), then direct you to the items that fit those

for next level AI-type of stuff, I recently came across those guys : <http://www.sentient.ai/shoes-com-expands-use-of-sentient-aware-across-eight-more-shoe-categories-releases-updated-user-experience-2/>
which, if you remove all the marketing copy BS (sorry) is actually pretty interesting once you translate that into a bot :simple_smile: (at least from my point of view)
<http://operator.com> is trying to do the shopping vertical as well, mix of human + bots right now still, I think
yeah, they sound pretty interesting as well

back to the question from <@U055FHACC> & <@U0HLC2479> I am indeed wondering whats the best UX & what will work in the end. The “show me $10 men tshirts” implies 1/you know already what you want to buy (bots can make recommendations based on that, but still pretty specific), and 2/you know how to type your request (no kidding, but once this becomes mainstream, your bot won't be able to handle 90% of the requests except if you have some solid NLP :D)
the “guided” FB-example one may be more robust & drive more conversion since it doesn't go directly to the specifics + you don't need much input from the user actually

Very different use cases to be fair. I suspect it will come on Messenger at some point

It's not so much about whether bots can merely join a chat or not, I bet that's easy. It's developing the intelligence that lets bots actually understand what's going on, and Facebook seems to be a step ahead in parts thanks to Wit.
It'd be interesting to understand the differences in handling 1-1 conversations (it's clear the individual user is interacting directly with the bot, which is expected to reply) from 1-n conversations (harder, the bot needs to identify direct interactions but also understand interactions between other participants, then it needs to interject appropriately)...

Hey guys, has anybody tried doing a delayed bot response? Consecutive bot.reply makes the bot post so fast that it doesn't seem too... organic? Delayed replies could make it seem more human
<@U0XEXKYSV>: <https://dev4slack.slack.com/archives/general/p1460133394001097>
<@U0CS6NSF5>: Thanks!
np :simple_smile:

<@U0XEXKYSV>: Yes, I'm doing that with the bot I've been working on (<http://getyoursidekick.org|getyoursidekick.org>). I actually also use the "is typing" indicator, and then I delay the message based on its length, but with a maximum 2 or 3 seconds.
That way, the responses are not so robotic/abrupt, but also, the user doesn't have to wait for a big chunk of data to load for the sake of "realism".
(Although I'd like to note that I belong to the school of thought that says you shouldn't make your bots appear to be humans, the delay is really just about the abruptness.)

Hey, I'm wondering if it's possible to prevent Slack from merging messages with each other. I want to send messages from my bot with different `icon_url` and/or `username`s. But the messages get shown under the first `icon_url` and `username`.

<@U0QTSKUH2>: Slack will not show a new icon if the user_id is the same and the messages are less than 5 mins between them. because they are from the same user_id, they show all together. anyway I agree that if the username is different they shouldn't be merged, you should ask Slack about that, maybe they can change it (at least on web). create a help request in your slack team. with a user, it sends it as coming from the user

<@U0YQS1FAR> <@U0GT29N3A> :  thanks for suggestions!  i ended up replacing with look alike unicode chars:
```
function escapeMessageFormattingChars(text){
    // slack doesn't let us escape message formatting characters.
    // messages are either formatted or not! this is problematic, when
    // a bot wants to create a formatted message that includes user generated
    // text, such as document titles. So since we can't escape, we replace
    // the relevant formatting chars (`, *, _, ~, <, > ) with unicode 'twins',
    // i.e. unicode chars that look similar but wont cause slack to interpret
    // them as formatting characters.

    var escapedText = text;

    // replace 'grave accent' (U+0060) with 'reversed prime' (U+2035)
    escapedText = escapedText.replace(/`/g, "‵");

    // replace 'asterisk' (U+002A) with 'heavy asterisk' (U+2731)
    escapedText = escapedText.replace(/\*/g, "✱");

    // replace 'low line' (U+005F) with 'fullwidth low line' (U+FF3F)'
    escapedText = escapedText.replace(/_/g, "＿");

    // replace 'tilde' (U+005F) with 'fullwidth tilde' (U+FF5E)'
    escapedText = escapedText.replace(/~/g, "⁓");

    // replace 'greater-than sign' (U+003E) with 'single right-pointing angle quotation mark' (U+203A)
    escapedText = escapedText.replace(/>/g, "›");

    // replace 'less-than sign' (U+003C) with 'single left-pointing angle quotation mark' (U+2039)
    escapedText = escapedText.replace(/</g, "‹");

    return escapedText;
}
```

the order a pizza fallacy is that all bot ai engine offer this as an example
while it's an extremely lousy example in my opinion, much more taps that clicking on the pizza you like in a browser/mobile app
like <@U0GT29N3A> described
one solution is webviews, images and so on, like wechat
that's basically due to very basic NLP interactions
but in general I say to people - don't confuse NLP/AI/bots with messaging apps
you can do: > deliver 3 pepperoni pizzas with onion ASAP
and answer many questions at once
NLP != turning a form with multiple fields into multiple bot questions
start either with command line rigid syntax - add NLP later to fluidify stuff - like <@U055FHACC> or <@U0GRN5Q3G> did beautifully
but turning a phrase into multiple form fields and ask for any extra information
or start with human interaction, add NLP later to automatize

difficulty is not commensurate to rewards

allowing for asynchronous, convenient interaction, cross platform apps, long tails effects

hey, guys, came here because I'm confused about how botkit "automatically" uses the built-in storage. It seems to me that you always have to save data in it yourself and retrieve it manually later. <@U14SCJSMV>: it's nice to have *one* way of doing things across the board I guess
and it's a really well designed wrapper
if you don't have much other stuff to do, it's very useful
I've copied the wrapper to use in other mongo project, not bot related
very clean
<@U0HBN0L9M>: okay, that makes sense. But the documentation mentions that botkit uses the storage module "automatically" when dealing with slack button apps. Can you explain what that means?
Another reason is that on some systems (like Heroku) you can't write persistently to the file system
and botkit writes to .json files to persist the data. So in our case we needed to use a database
Ah, I misread the question
the automatic part is
that when using the slack button oauth
it stores information using the built in storage system
friendly reminder! <http://arstechnica.com/security/2016/04/hacking-slack-accounts-as-easy-as-searching-github/>
And a follow up from Slack <https://medium.com/slack-developer-blog/slack-tokens-what-they-are-how-theyre-used-and-how-to-keep-your-data-safe-ed1b00d2715a#.dpkk0b886>

Tonight's reading in here has been great. I started all Gung Ho 3-4 months ago, developing 2 bots with <#C0AV5N8NA>. I made them both work great, even reprogrammed both several times to add validation but mostly a better UI and experience. That was the easy part, despite being new to Node.js among other things. Mostly thanks to many of you writing this evening. But where it all came to a crashing halt (several trips and funerals notwithstanding) is when I was ready to launch.
At that time, the same players were discussing encryption and scaling. Since that time I have tried several different data storage approaches, hosting approaches (AWS, DigitalOcean, and $$Google$Cloud$Platform$$). Information, or better yet, code examples of both 'great' encryption and scaling have been very hard to come by. So I have been learning, trying, but mostly seeing hundreds of other bots launching.
It's been frustrating, but after seeing the articles of the token/data leakage (ew), I can say in hindsight, that my fear of launching may have been grounded in reality, and I'm happy I didn't do it half-assed.
Now I'm finally starting to see some of this hard to come by info/code examples starting to make their way out there, thankfully. Perhaps there is still hope these bots see the light of day before the critics and poorly designed ones do more damage to the new newness. I plan to document my experience for other n00bs soon here and that other medium everyone posts everything on now.
that'd be awesome
<@U0HUZ214H>: not only you'd be sharing important lessons (& code samples?) but also you'd be reminding people that security is important
I think you took the right path
we discussed with <@U0D7LHNTX> that they might be going to share some security related best practices
<@U0HUZ214H>: bear in mind these news are equivalent to people tweeting their gmail username and password, it's about pure negligence rather than poor engineering

the worst part about this whole situation is the message “Slack bots are a big security threat and are going to leave you exposed”, which will make more teams restrict installing bots to only admins, which will in turn limit the growth of bots

on the other hand, bots really are a security threat, and you have to take security seriously and be ready to have detailed conversations about privacy and security with big companies who will want to use your bot, these kind of news will scare smaller companies into not installing bots too
Very true <@U0CS6NSF5>. Got to get ahead of this.
Thanks <@U0HBN0L9M> for the encouragement.

I'm occasionally getting `invalid_auth` back from the RTM API. The docs just say it's an Invalid Authentication Token, but it doesn't say what would cause that to happen. <https://api.slack.com/methods/rtm.start>. Anyone know what causes an auth token to be invalid? It only happens to 5 of our 312 teams.
<@U0YQS1FAR>: a wrong token, although they have sometimes made changes that would return `invalid_auth` when they were supposed to return something like `token_revoked`
Thanks <@U0CS6NSF5>. Wrong token as in it doesn't belong to that team? The latter seems more likely in this case
<@U0YQS1FAR>: wrong token as in `token` contains an string that doesn't correspond to a token. e.g: if you send `token=whatever` you would get an `invalid_auth`
ah, interesting. Thanks

We don't do anything to work around it right now

It's not a huge deal right now… we just had a customer unexpectedly using guest Slack accounts and none of those users could sign in.

<@U0HRQBPE1>: in my opinion, SIWS should be available for guests, maybe without the `identity.team` scope, but having it 100% disabled will hurt some use cases. But there's other issues regarding permissions that are more important from my point of view
Bots being able to access a channel's history, which is important for reliability and missing
Bots able to leave channels, which is related to a bug they had (I don't know if it's fixed yet) where you can have inaccessible private channels
Bots being able to create private channels and invite users, which means for some use cases you need to ask for `groups:read` scopes
Etc.
<@U0HPNTZ8Q>: good luck getting with that one... XD it's more feasible to get access to that with a user's token
Rather than a bot
Given that bots don't even have access to historical data at all

one of the things I wanted to do would have been trivial with a search using `in:`, `has:link` and `on:` modifiers
You can always keep track of that yourself

Hello everyone, I'm trying to create a channel using bot, but the problem is I'm not able to set the purpose with the request. Here's what I've tried: "<https://slack.com/api/channels.create?token=xoxp-39655532261-abcdefghij-abcdefghijk-abcdefghij&name=testChannel4&pretty=1&purpose=testing> channel from engazify"
"<https://slack.com/api/channels.create?token=xoxp-39655532261-abcdefghij-abcdefghijk-abcdefghij&name=testChannel4&pretty=1&purpose={value:testing> channel from engazify}" by changing channel names. The channels are getting created but purpose is not set. Here is docs link: <https://api.slack.com/methods/channels.create> What am I doing wrong?
<@U1621CQ95>: do you see the "purpose" parameter in `channels.create`?
You need to use `channels.setPurpose` and `channels.setTopic`, but I'm afraid this is not available for bot users: you'll need to use a user token with the `channels:write` scope for that.
<@U0GT29N3A>: thanks for reply. Does that mean `channels.setPurpose` should be called after creation of channel?
<@U1621CQ95>: yes, it's a different method, you can only call it after creating the channel (since you need the channel id)

<@U148BK6NM>: you request both the `bot` and `channels:write` scopes with the Add to Slack button and will receive two access tokens, one to act as the bot and another one for the user. With the user's access token you will be able to create channels as long as the user has permission to create channels in the team
<@U0CS6NSF5>: ahh..for example when I view team detailsI usually see 2 tokens, one for bot and another for createdBy
With the right scope on the user token you can create channels :)
What you would be doing is: open a channel with the user token, invite the bot to the channel with the same token
There are some caveats: a user cannot invite a bot/user to a channel it is not part of

Hi all, I'm having some trouble with oauth flow - specifically the `redirect_uri`s. I'm finding that I must only use the url I provide in my app's config. All others produce an error. Can anyone help me understand this better?
I believe it's for security - so no one else can put ‘your' add to slack button, and get users auth tokens under the guise of being your app
you can control which url's are allowed to receive the credentials
you can add multiple url's there
but you have to manually add them to verify those are ones you control and are listening to

I've tried listing two different urls in the config: `<http://myapp.com/a|myapp.com/a>` and `<http://myapp.com/b|myapp.com/b>`. My Add To Slack button has `redirect_uri=<http://myapp.com/a|myapp.com/a>`. And this works. When I need to exchange the code for a token, I set the `redirect_uri=<http://myapp.com/b|myapp.com/b>` and this produces `bad_redirect_uri` error.
<https://api.slack.com/methods/oauth.access>
looks like if you want to pass a redirect_uri in that call it has to match the original one
I remember reading that now that you mention it - so this means you must use a single endpoint to receive the code and token - correct? That seems strange to me. Is that normally how it's done?
yeah that looks right
not sure how typical that is
If this is the case, that endpoint would have to basically inspect the request data to know whether it's dealing with the code or token. Wouldn't it be cleaner to have separate endpoints?
Ok, thanks <@U14H7AYJU> would be interesting to understand this more, but I can move forward now.. thanks again.

<@U1G1G4HED> The call to `oauth.access` is an API call. It's not a URL you send the user to, and no redirect happens. So your `redirect_uri` handles exactly one case: when the user has authorized (or not) your app and you're being delivered an authorization code. After that, you make an API call to `oauth.access` and receive an access token in the API response.
(The reason the `oauth.access` call takes a `redirect_uri` is just to check that it matches the `redirect_uri` used when the authorization code was obtained in the first place.)

Hi guys. I am cleaning channels in one of my slack team. In fact, I would be able to merge <#C04SM6TAX> and <#C04SM6TAK>, as they both deserve the same goal: chit-chat, out of topic talks. There is nothing about merging in channel settings, so how would you achieve this ? Thank you for tricks/hints

<@U0K7U9LUC> -> don't think it's possible to merge channel content like that, it was requested some time ago, but it's not been implemented from what I've seen: <https://twitter.com/slackhq/status/465666187545051136>
<@U1DM2B4SY>: I came to same conclusion, thus why I asked for some _tricks_

You can probably write a bot to gather all messages in Channel A, all messages in Channel B, and write them all to Channel C, but is that really worth it? When we went through the same type of thing, we just gave our users about a weeks notice to wrap up conversations in Channel A, informing them we'd be moving those types of chats to Channel B, then when the date came we archived Channel A so it was still searchable but not writeable

You can export your channel data (<http://my.slack.com/services/export>) and then import (<http://my.slack.com/services/import>) just <#C04SM6TAX> -> <#C04SM6TAK> ... _however_ we've mostly heard regret with merging channels this way. Archives can become very confusing in the event two simultaneous conversations are combined.

hello... ! question wrt scopes and add-to-slack access request. the only scope we're asking for is groups:write. The access request it seems to be translating into is "we'll be able to modify information about your private channels, including name and purpose, as well as archive and create new ones..".
we're definitely unable to modify, name, purpose, archive any pvt channels that our bot itself didn't create. The access-request-message above is misleading for someone looking to integrate. any advice?
<@U0GGT8K88>: I think you mean groups:write... that will be added to the "user token", not the "bot token"... so the user needs to be a member of the group IMO
the problem with "groups" is that only members have access to them, so "others" can't do things on them
<@U11FSNKL0>: you're right, groups:write. the bot creates pvt channels in other teams for its team members to sync with certain pvt channels in our own team.
the bot creates the channel... or the user token? if you go to a group, it says created by @botname?
no if you're the admin of the team (or the person that integrated) it'll say <@U11FSNKL0> created the team
right, so that user needs to be a member of the group... then using the user token (that is from that user) you can change the purpose, etc...
don't use the bot token, use the user token

<@U11FSNKL0>: right, i believe that's what we're doing to accomplishing the workflow... my concern is the add-to-slack access request message (above) that indicates to you that we have access to all your pvt channels
which isn't true

no... the user has access to the groups that user has access... and that user can do everything on those groups. is specific to groups. imagine you install a bot, and the bot can access all the groups that other users created, that would be a privacy problem
I can install a bot here, and read all groups from all users
mm, right, so, sorry, you agreeing with me that the message is misleading? :slightly_smiling_face:
I mean I see your point... but I don't think Slack will change anything about it...
'your private channels'; i think I get that 'your' in that message refers to you <@U11FSNKL0> and not to the team
hmm... i see
yes, the user <@U11FSNKL0> that installed the bot

<@U1JC7HJMC> you will need to ask for additional scopes to send a DM from a slash command. Slash commands are designed for one-off interactions where you send a single response to a single command. Hello, I have a couple of issues I was thinking of raising on GitHub, but thought to bring it up here quickly to see if it's worth my time

Both relate to botkit/Facebook.js: Comparing Facebook's sample app with Botkit's implementation, I notice that the latter lacks the former's function that verifies that the callback came from Facebook, specifically <https://github.com/fbsamples/messenger-platform-samples/blob/master/node/app.js#L112> onwards. Is this something that you think should be included in facebook_botkit.setupWebserver?

The other issue relates to adding an address argument to `facebook_botkit.setupWebserver` to line up with `express().listen`. Openshift requires node developers to supply both the host and the port in order for the listening process to receive messages from the outside world, per <https://blog.openshift.com/run-your-nodejs-projects-on-openshift-in-two-simple-steps/>. I'm aware that one can bring-your-own express, though it would be nice if Botkit could do it out of the box.

Hello guys, Is it possible to remove/replace the message (the one with interactive button) even if the user did not click any of its buttons, let say in a period of time if the user didn't click any of the button the message will be destroy or replace with another message. I had really hard time understanding some part of the documentation.

<@U0TGHKPEU>: if you have the `message_ts` for the posted message and the right OAuth scopes to use `chat.update`, you should be able to update a message based on your own business logic (like waiting after a period of time to modify the message)
Thanks <@U07CW6N3A> , but how should I get that `message_ts`, im using chat.postMessage method to send message with button to a user, and there is no option for chat.postMessage to set a `message_ts`

It's more difficult to obtain when a user hasn't clicked a message (since the `original_message` along with its timestamp is included in an invoked action). The most likely way you would retrieve it is by keeping a websocket connection open to the RTM API. Another way would be to periodically retrieve recent messages from `channels.history`. It's a little clunky.
Hmm, yeah that would be a little clunky since I'm not really into RTM API, I think i will find some other way around. :slightly_smiling_face: thanks for confirming <@U07CW6N3A>,
<@U0TGHKPEU>: in <https://api.slack.com/methods/chat.postMessage> it says that the response of chat.postMessage has the message ts, you should get it from there (didn't try it...)

Hey guys, I've created a slack app for our internal purposes. The app has an incoming webhook which posts a message to certain channel. The message is basically a question and has five buttons named `1`, `2` and so on till `5`. Our slack users, click on a button and rate the question for which my slack endpoint in our application responds with an `ephemeral` response telling the user the rating they have given in a new message.
What I really want to do is, I want to update the original question with the response message and not a new message.
And it should be ephemeral.
<@U1KH878SJ>: I believe that as you originally posted “public” that can not be changed afterwards
The original message can be updated as is visible in the documentation.
That I'm sure about.
yes
but no the type of message
"Once a message has been issued, it will retain its visibility quality for life."
<https://api.slack.com/docs/message-buttons>
The whole point is to post the response message just right next to the original question.
Yes, I read that.
That works as expected.
Suppose, in the time user clicked on an action button, a new question came in from the webhook, the response to the previous question will be posted after the 2nd question which is not what I want.
I see what you mean now .. and unfortunately I dont have a suggestion on how to solve that
unless in your “ephemeral” response you make a reference to the original question
check the time between question and response and if it is too long you can “assume” that there was more activity in the channel

<@U0JPS3SHX>: I did a work around. I removed the `ephemeral` condition from it, and now I am updating the original question with `original_message` and attached a new element to `attachments` key which serves the purpose of response.
It looks fine now.
<@U1KH878SJ>: but visible to everyone right ?
yes, that's correct.
since the visibility can't be changed, I talked to my boss if it could remain public and they agreed.
since there's nothing we can do to change it.

tako: Redis is a key/value store with extras- it doesn't provide real relational persistence the way an SQL store does. They each have their strengths and there is a bit of overlap in functionality. The other thing about redis is it's bloody fast and schemaless, so you can get your app off the ground more quickly.

Hello. I am looking for an experienced freelance node developer who can provide some consultancy and further development on projects.
The first immediate project is a chatbot built with botkit.js - we would like you to review the code written so far and provide advice on issues like encapsulation (modularisation), design patterns, best practices etc. The project is on github, with a README that documents how to install and set up on heroku. It's very simple at the moment with only a few hundred lines of code.
The second step is to add a UI. We will need advice on the which framework to use and assistance with the development.
You must: * Have a broad knowledge of full-stack Node/js technologies and be able to compare their pros and cons (e.g meteor / angular / react etc.) * Have experience doing code reviews * Have experience architecting micro-services applications using task queues * Have experience with multiple js-based test frameworks * Be an expert-level js / node developer with strong computer science fundamentals.
If you're interested please get in touch via Slack

Hi there, for those of you curious about the possibility of a direct Install button from the Slack App Directory instead of a link to your website, we did an experiment. We sent half of the traffic from the App Directory to our website and half straight to the authentication page, then tallied how many of each group signed up. You can read the whole story here: <https://medium.com/@mailclarkteam/a-b-testing-sign-up-strategies-from-the-slack-app-directory-6a9425707880>

:wave: I come bearing great news on this fine Tuesday! Our latest feature — Admin-Approved Apps — just went live to all Slack teams :rocket: The apps you build on Slack are pretty great. And we want to make it easy for everyone to appreciate just how great they are. Admins are always looking for new controls to make their job as pain-free as can be :face_with_head_bandage: So, today's feature gives admins a more flexible permission to easily deploy apps for their team — with the Approved Apps setting, Team Owners (and select others) can choose which apps are OK for _every_ team member to install and use. But, that's not all. Team members can also _request_ apps that they'd like to use at work...to do great work.
Here's why this is exciting for you: :key: With this new control, we have a hunch that admins with locked down app settings will open up their app permissions. :white_check_mark: This feature launch calls attention to the _many_ apps we have available in our App Directory and encourages admins to check them out. :mega: You now have app advocates in every Slack team! We've created a new line of communication for team members to tell admins which apps they need to do their best work in Slack.
Oh, and the neatest part? We built this feature with our very own message buttons :button: See how we did it —> <https://medium.com/slack-developer-blog/building-admin-approved-apps-461612d4c0c5#.vnrvc9yuz>

have a question about how interactive messages.. Say i post a interactive message in the general channel, with a button, is there a way i can change the message per user after they click on one of the buttons..Currently when i post response to the respone_url, it replaces the message for everyone.... I was curious if there is a way to send customized message ...

no, you would have to send an ephemeral message (viewable only by the one user) to all users, instead of posting directly in the channel, and ephemeral messages are currently only in response to slash commands if my understanding is correct, so it could not be initiated by you

thanks for response...I can send ephemeral message, indicating some response to each user.... When i looked at Lunchtrian example slack showed in their video, i got a impression that it is possible to modify the message for each of the users depending on the response

You can modify the original message, but the modifications will appear to each user that can view the message. So if User A clicks a button, you can change the message to acknowledge that User A clicked it, but Users B and C will also see that updates message.

On the other hand, when User A clicks a button, there are a few things you can do in response. You could change the original message, or you can respond directly with an ephemeral message that only User A would see. You can also use the provided `response_url` to continue making message updates.

Depending on how complex your workflow is, you might be coordinating a whole concert of progressive interactions across many users, eventually coalescing all that activity into modifying the original message after all the paths have forked and completed.

yeah...currently i am sending a ephemeral message to acknowledge the user (The other issue i found is it does not auto scroll to the lastest message) My workflow is similar to taking a poll with in a channel....it gets little tough to update the same message when respondents increase beyond 5,6 people

What I would do is set a distinct `callback_id` for your poll, that way you can correlate any interactions with the message back to that callback_id instance. Once you've published the originating message, also take note of the TS value for the message. Then use `chat.update` to finally update the message once the poll is closed using that TS value. Reserve all your responses to incoming actions or usage of response_url to just momentary ephemeral messages and acknowledgements. Might help make things less spaghetti-like.
thats a good idea..thanks for that

<@U1TMT1R1C>: if you're using botkit's example named `slackbutton_bot_interactivemsg.js` and if you use the botkit's pre-defined and default express server... when they call the following method:

``` controller.setupWebserver(process.env.port,function(err,webserver) {
  controller.createWebhookEndpoints(controller.webserver);

  controller.createOauthEndpoints(controller.webserver,function(err,req,res) {
    if (err) {
      res.status(500).send('ERROR: ' + err);
    } else {
      res.send('Success!');
    }
  });
});  ```

Then it will auto-configure the endpoint for the interactive messages callback to be wherever your host your app plus `/slack/receive`

So let's see this.. if i were to be running that example on localhost using a tunnel like ngrok

then the url i would put there would be something like this:

`<https://my-ngrok-address.io/slack/receive>`
cause the method that botkit has `createOauthEndpoints` sets up the interactive messages callback to that `/slack/receive` endpoint

Hello everyone!
Today the Slack platform team released the Events API, a way for your Slack apps to subscribe to specific team events and have them pushed to your server. :lightning:
:mag_right: Focus just on the event types you need and don't worry about maintaining open websocket connections for every team or user you work with. :four_leaf_clover:
> Our announcement covers some of the typical use cases: <https://medium.com/slack-developer-blog/subscribe-to-the-events-api-d7120470983f#.u9n3rc58x>
> The documentation walks you through configuration and processing events: <https://api.slack.com/events-api>
> Browse the available event types: <https://api.slack.com/events/api>
We're excited to see what you build with the Events API! When used in conjunction with the Web API, it's possible to build (& scale) bot users entirely over HTTP.

We're definitely cognizant of the inconsistencies between API types in the platform. Some of them are trickier than others when honoring historical choices. In the Events API, for example, we're bound by the existing structure of events sent in the RTM API, though we have the luxury of "wrapping" those existing event types with additional, more modern metadata, we also erred on the side of being non-duplicative.

The way of addressing user IDs in message buttons is definitely a more modern approach that we can't easily backport to slash commands and event payloads in a non-breaking and non-duplicative way, though we'd definitely prefer consistency across features.

<@U1TMT1R1C>: I have a bot similar to yours. I have the following setup: Bot code in open source (<https://github.com/prongs/lens-slack-bot>). The bot reads token and some more details from a config file. Now, I have installed that in one of the server machines. With two helper files: 


```
lens@server-machine:/usr/local/lens/bot$ cat lensbot.js
var LensSlackBot = require("lens-slack-bot");
var bot = new LensSlackBot();
bot.start();
lens@server-machine:/usr/local/lens/bot$ cat startbot.sh
while true; do
rm -rf /tmp/npm-*
npm install git+<https://github.com/prongs/lens-node-client.git>
npm install git+<https://github.com/prongs/lens-slack-bot.git>
ps -ef | grep node | grep lensbot | grep -v grep | awk '{print $2}' | xargs -L1 kill -9
node lensbot.js;
sleep 60;
done &
lens@server-machine:/usr/local/lens/bot$```

This makes sure the bot is always up. The 60 second interval can be reduced as per the requirement. Turns out, this bot stays up for days and the 60 second downtime occurs once a week or so. I have the following in the app's code that might be resulting in such a behaviour: 

```controller.on('tick', () => {
      const now = new Date();
      if (now.getTime() - this.lastActiveTime.getTime() > 1000 * 60) { // 1 minute idle timeout
        this.bot.say({type: "ping", id: now.getTime()}, this.updateLastActiveTime);
      }
    });```

With these two mechanisms, I'm able to keep my bot up practically indefinitely.

One simple question, im trying to response a message with "ephemeral" attribute. That attibute works with chat.portMessage or needs Node.JS to work?
ephemeral messages can only be sent in response to a slash command
also node isn't necessary for the slack api, anything that talks http will do (botkit is node of course)
Thanks for solve my doubt :slightly_smiling_face:

Ephemeral messages can also be sent in response to message button clicks -- it's a kind of common scenario between slash command invocations and message buttons -- a user has demonstrated activity and created an situation/context where an ephemeral message is welcome and likely to be read/interacted with. Right now, Slack just doesn't support ephemeral messages being created without that additional context/inciting action.

Hi <@U14H7AYJU> :wave::skin-tone-2: I wanted to answer your question on app releases!
>After you submit your app to the app directory, the App Review team will work with you through out the review process, so if you'd like to release the app on a certain day they can help with that, provided the app's been approved *prior to the launch date* you're looking for. > >Since each app is unique the review period can vary pretty dramatically from app to app, though making sure your app has _everything_ included in the *app review checklist* is a great way to expedite the review process. I will also mention that the App Review team is full of really incredible humans who review apps as soon as they can. :robot_face: > >Just for handy reference, here's the *app review checklist*: <https://api.slack.com/docs/slack-apps-checklist>

Hey everyone, we are researching how to integrate our app with Slack, in a two-way sync approach.

funny since slack seems to know it for your profile
<@U0LKH699P>: it's in the profile object for a user but it's optional

<@U0CT32R88>: when a user signs in to your app with slack you get a temporary token for that user. You can then use the RTM to read and write as that user, provided you have included those scopes.
They are quite invasive scopes so you will probably need a good privacy policy and give clients a lot of reassurance that you won't be up to no good.
Thank you for helping out <@U0LR6R73K> - What about the rate limits?
<@U0LKH699P>: sorry, I misread, I thought about FB bots
Actually I don't know if there is a scope for that. I have made similar things but using user generated test tokens
<@U0CT32R88>: I run <http://www.smooz.io|www.smooz.io> and you can use a bot for that
Rate limits will be per token, I believe
hmm, not for the direct messages though
I am worried that the rate limit is for all of them
I don't feel like rate limit will be your issue
could you tell me why please
two reasons. one is that rate limit seem to block loops (like programming mistakes where you send inifinite messages)
the threshold seems quite different from human input, as far as I can tell
secondly
you could always slow down typing
users won't notice a small delay in reply
messaging is asynchronous conversation
no, your problem will be having access to private messages
if I understand correclty your use-case
I just checked, rate limit is 1 message / second
unless you have a very big and very active team, that sounds reasonnable

Hey everyone -- Keith from <http://Abe.ai|Abe.ai> here. We're experimenting with a new Slack onboarding flow for our personal finance bot and would appreciate your feedback. Please watch our 2:06 video and share your constructive comments: <https://abe.wistia.com/medias/dj8xqkhhab> :clap:
To add some context … Abe studies your cash flow and tells you how money cash you have to work with every 7 days. He also allows you to schedule a call with a Certified Financial Planner. There has been recent promotion of using AWS Lambda to build Slack integrations (eg bot users, slash commands) and the experience is mostly good. <https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/aws/new-slack-integration-blueprints-for-aws-lambda/>

Hi there, I'm having a trouble when I try to use interactive messages with a bot user, because when I press an option automatically slack bot says "Oops something went wrong". Has anyone knows whats going on?
<@U2908LWTY> u probably need to setup your intereactive messages endpoint on your slack app
if you are using botkit, and use the `controller.createOauthEndpoints` method
then it will setup the interactive messages endpoint at `yourhost:3001/slack/receive`
so you go to yourslack app menu... go to the interactive messages option and set up the endpoint there
are you sure that would work <@U1116QM2Q> ? I don't think it's a redirect
I would think you'd need to use ngrok or localtunnel to expose the endpoint
usually when slack gives you the `something went wrong` its causet he endpoint is not set :stuck_out_tongue:
and yes i didn't mention that detail
like <http://mylocaldev.localtunnel.me/slack/receive|mylocaldev.localtunnel.me/slack/receive>
but your "host" needs to have SSL enabled
so usually what we do
is use either localtunnel or ngrok to setup a tunnel to your server
localtunnel is HTTPS
and that handles the SSL part
yep
with localtunnel you can save a subdomain with your bot name so you don't have to keep changing it in slack: `lt --port 4115 --subdomain yourbot`

Want to build something and looking for an idea? Here's what I need, I imagine other bot builders need that too: *Dialogue manager* to manage the bot's responses in various situation. Ideally it would support: -Branching (if this then say that, otherwise say the other thing) -Multiple responses for the same situation (so that bot won't repeat himself) -Nice: Smart way to pick the best response right now (eg based on sentiment analysis from previous users) -Multi platform support (because *bold* is “*” in Slack and <strong></strong> in HipChat) -Multi language support, because not everyone speaks English -Allow the dialog team to work separately on their side, and hot-deploy changes into the bot without bothering the devs for anything -Some kind of light simulation - run the dialog inside the editor to get a feel for how it looks inside Slack, Facebook etc. [Does anyone know a tool that comes close to doing this?]
<@U055FHACC> _-Allow the dialog team to work separately on their side, and hot-deploy changes into the bot without bothering the devs for anything_ is the most important IMHO

dev could work on the bot engine while content managers could change the wordings, and the two services would talk to each other like an API

<@U055FHACC>: I want the same. Many bots are just decision trees (ordering pizza for example) and it should be possible to create a simple GUI editor to create questions and answers and then assign an outcome to the end of the tree. I have looked but cannot find anything (even a decision tree editor not related to bots). The difference between a Dev changing content and a business user is huge.. Cause after a while when the project matures no one is starting an it project or begging for a developer to make a few small changes or do AB testing on text.

looks like the majority of products aim for the “build a bot with no coding” crowd. That's okay for fun projects or small businesses experimenting. But for the bigger, more serious projects this is like offering you WordArt when you need Photoshop. When you have to manage thousands of branching response strings, these tools are not the answer.

> <@U0HBN0L9M> _we worked at separating the bot engine and the content structure into two separate modules_ We've done pretty much the same at <http://MailClark.ai|MailClark.ai> a few months ago :wink: Writing bot conversations and coding the bot engine are indeed two different things so a Dialogue Manager as you described <@U055FHACC> would be a great tool. A Conversation Management System. For the back-office UI, I reckon scriptwriting software (e.g. Adobe Story or Highland) could provide an interesting source of inspiration. Writing for bots—which is all about flows—doesn't relate much to writing for websites—which is all about pages—so I believe traditional CMS interfaces wouldn't do the job.

> <@U055FHACC> _Allow the dialog team to work separately on their side, and hot-deploy changes into the bot without bothering the devs for anything_ The COPE model invited by Daniel Jacobson at NPR back in 2009 could apply to what you describe here. <http://www.programmableweb.com/news/cope-create-once-publish-everywhere/2009/10/13>

So, when building a Slack App, does it have to go through the app directory to use for a private team?
nop
I'm trying to utilize interactive messages for an internal app, not looking to build something that others can use
but I don't see a way to enable it for my team, only how to submit it to the app directory

You can create a slack app and never submit it to the directory. You could provide the installation URL or sign in URLs only to members of your team. You could further limit which teams could install your slack app within your own app, by revoking tokens/ignoring installation attempts from any team IDs not matching your whitelist.
But there's no way right now to completely limit who can attempt to install your app, provided they had the client ID corresponding to your app.
It shouldn't be too hard to limit installation to only your team and I can imagine Slack providing better ways to do so in the future.
so, I set up the slash commands and bot users, which is all I need
do I have to setup the oauth piece? even though I'm not going to use it? I get a big warning on every page
also, I still don't see any url or anything to install the thing, just the ability to submit to the app directory, how do I actually get to the install url?

You will have to go through the OAuth process -- someone will need to install the app and your app will have to answer the redirect, process the verification code, and negotiate that access token, which then gives your app access to your team's goodies via the scopes you ask for. It's easier than it all sounds. The installation URL is actually the "oauth authorize" step of the OAuth 2.0 flow -- you can easily generate one over on the "Add to Slack Button" documentation: <https://api.slack.com/docs/slack-button#add_the_slack_button>
yeah, just found that
thanks for the help

Is there a way to allow only one action (out of all presented) to be taken? I mean I send notification to channel with e.g. 4 actions and would like to allow only the first action to be invoked and subsequent to be discarded
I was thinking on doing this on my side with something like `runningActions` bag, where I'd put `ts` of original message on callback arrival and'd clean this up upon finishing

why would you present 4 buttons?
there are 4 possible actions and I want sth like 'first hit wins'
I could update the message as soon as action gets run (remove buttons to prevent from subsequent clicks), but that's always the network... cannot rely on it
also it doesn't work well when there is confirmation dialog attached to button (action gets executed upon confirmation even if message was updated and buttons were removed)
that's why I was thinking on doing this by keeping list of ids of messages for which callbacks are running, but again - it fails with confirmation e.g. in the following scenario:

1. user A hits button 'foo' 2. user A gets confirmation and hits 'ok' 3. in the meantime user B hits 'bar' 4. user B gets confirmation and waits a bit 5. A's action finishes (and running callback gets removed from the list) 6. user B hits 'ok' result => B's action gets executed
hmm, now I'm thinking about that and maybe it's not an issue... I do checks on my side anyway whether an action can be run or not... :rubber_duck:
Hello everybody.

<@U2CC83EET> this doesn't really help you, but note that the buttons will be disabled for the user who clicked them until Slack receives your response. So if you remove the buttons via your response then the same user can never click a second button. But a different user can, as you've said.
so I would suggest using your response to remove the buttons if you aren't already, rather than making a separate call to the Web API — it will minimize network time

What are the best practices for writing automated API tests for a slack api wrapper?
Any suggestions? Right now I'm just posting messages, and uhhh...checking them by eye, for example
I don't think there _are_ best practices yet
You can mock out the HTTP layer and validate that what you're sending to the API _looks_ right, but that won't catch things like `>` characters being sent to your app as `&gt;`s.
It'd be ideal if the platforms would publish a rendering tool, so you could send it a blob of JSON and get back HTML or whatever. Then you could do DOM queries for correctness on the actual output.
I wonder if you could abuse the Slack Message Builder for that <https://api.slack.com/docs/messages/builder>
<@U1BPBKXK5> Good to know :slightly_smiling_face: Aight - I'll just do this by hand for now, but...I'll consider my options

<@U0HBN0L9M> for these it's best to go right to support -- the reason might be subtle. your hypothesis is definitely a good one, but since multiple users might install a bot, yielding multiple user tokens but just one bot user token, it could be that the originally installing user has removed the app but some other existing user that installed it is still puttering along

I won't be able to go to support with that issue, because it's not in my team. it's really an API issue, isn't it

The support team helps both team admins and app developers pretty well. I suggest them because they're best equipped to give you the answer that's right for this particular situation and might be able to tell you exactly how that team's lingering install is modeled. The Slack app install and uninstall model can be a little complex still, with all the actors and pseudo-actors involved.
is it possible to implement conversations in slack without using a Slack App? Say, in response to a slash command?
<@U2G6XRJ5V> Sort of. Your slash command would have to do the persistence between requests, but you do get a user id so you know you're talking to the same person.

```token=aWoE7Ofc9FQGKbizrs6FM5wf team_id=T0001 team_domain=example channel_id=C2147483705 channel_name=test user_id=U2147483697 user_name=Steve command=/weather text=94070 response_url=<https://hooks.slack.com/commands/1234/5678> ```
So if you take the team_id + user_id you have a unique presence.
even + channel_id if you want it to be channel-specific.

if you use lambda with python you will probably hit the >3sec issue as well

one way around it in lambda is to have two functions fronted by an API gateway.. have the first lambda take the request ... lets call that the dispatcher.. and then immediately respond back with a 200.. then using the slack response_url you can have your second lambda take up to 5 mins to process and it can post back remotely
<@U2LJS1E2Y>, that's how we have been using to send delayed responses so far. works like a charm. Return 200 immediately and later use the response_url to update or add the message.
<@U23KZ4R8V> thanks
<@U2ATR2KV1>: from what I remember from reading the Slack API yes

<@U2ATR2KV1> for bot users that aren't part of a Slack app, you can specify an `icon_url` as part of your message, to give that specific message a different profile image. bot users that are part of Slack apps can't change their icon on demand that way though. And in neither case does changing the icon go beyond the message in question. There is a Web API method to update a user's profile image, but it won't let you update a bot user's. There is no other way to programmatically update a bot user's image, whether as part of a Slack app or otherwise.

Hey all, I am creating a bot which will help my users interact with my SaaS HR app. Problem is, I really need some way to relate my Slack user to my HR app user login, so I know their permissions and what they are permitted to look at etc. Are there any 'best practice' guides out there for authenticating, or matching up a Slack user who interacts with a bot, with an external third party app? I know asking for passwords etc. within a channel conversation is an absolute no-no, so was thinking my SaaS app has to generate a unique token for each user or similar, that can be given to the bot when asked?

<@U2M7LE3E2>: I was doing this with a deployment app a little while back. The usual answer is to record a Slack-user-id <=> HR-app-user-id mapping in a database somewhere. It obviously can't be Slack, but it can be in your HR app's db, or in your bot's db. It helps if your HR app does some thing where you can store a token instead of username/password, but it all depends on the app.
But yeah, don't communicate credentials in Slack. Use HTTPS instead, and preferably OAuth so your app never sees username/password.

<@U1BPBKXK5> Thanks Ben! I was thinking along the token method - generate a unique "Slack Token" in my HR app, and when a user asks the bot for information, the bot will check its database for a Slack User -> HR All Slack Token match, and if not found, will DM the Slack user and ask for their token, which it then stores in the bot database for future use. Not 100% I know, and I will look into oAuth a little more, but I am unsure if I can obtain the Slack user and team IDs as part of the oAuth handshake (on my app side, so I can match and save the info in the HR app db.
They're available through the API. If your app asks for the `team:info` permission, you can do lookups.
Also, whenever a user sends you a message, you get their Slack user id as part of the payload.
That's the ID I was talking about. No need to generate a new one for the Slack side.
Oh, and you get Team and User IDs as part of (I think) every Slack-app auth dance, even if it's just a /command.

<@U1BPBKXK5> Thanks for the clarification Ben. I will look into the permissions a little more. Just to confirm my assumption - the Slack USER ID stays consistent no matter how many Slack teams/organisations the user is interacting with or issuing bot commands via?
I think the rule of thumb here is (team ID + user ID) is globally unique. There's no guarantee that user IDs are unique across teams.

That's a key factor for us that I will need to confirm. Our web app is designed for HR consultants who may be working for several companies, hence may be in several Slack groups as part of their role. Getting a SlackTeamID and SlackUserID is crucial for us to ensure the bot they use is talking to the right HR dataset as the right user. It's pretty critical to us that the SlackUserID remains the same for the same user signed on to different Slack groups.
<@U2M7LE3E2> you should not rely on that
you should map your consultant's HR app ID to an array of teamID + UserID, I think
one way to avoid the token issue you discussed earlier, is to use the sign in with slack feature
within your HR app, you provide a SIWS button that will confirm the ID of the consultant within that team

Hey all - having an issue with the OAuth2.0 redirect_uri with trying to get people to authenticate with my bot. The issue is, my web app uses subdomains to identify company entities, so a user may be logged on to _company1.mydomain.com_ or _company2.mydomain.com_ etc. I have set up just _mydomain.com_ as an redirect URL within my app but the redirect keeps reporting "OAuth Error: redirect_uri did not match any configured URIs". Is there a workaround for this? I thought the redirect URI did a simple string match on a partial, but it looks like it does something different.
Did anyone else already rotated their verification token and still received the final reminder to do it?
<@U0GT29N3A> yes. i asked them about it and they said everyone got that message even if you already rotated
<@U2M7LE3E2> : the left-hand part must match
you can use `<http://mydomain.com/slack/whatever|mydomain.com/slack/whatever>` in your case

hey guys docs for sourcebot is out! <https://sourcebot.github.io/docs/>
Hey <@U0HERRQR1>, how does SourceBot differ from BotKit? The interface is chained methods but outside of that it appears to be about the same functionality, correct?
it is a bot framework
it aims to do the same thing
botkit uses promises and ES6
which is supported by node 4, 5, 6
sorry sourcebot uses promises and es6
on the other hand botkit uses ES5 and callbacks
the aim of sourcebot is to solve one problem: write code once and use it on multiple platforms
I get that. You're saying the major difference is promises instead of callbacks?
yes, the chance of your process to be exited on error is 0 if you use sourcebot
also we have a command line interface
```npm i sourcebot-cli -g```
and then u can make this:
```sourcebot create hello-world```
it will create a folder with a starter pack
I'm guessing there's no chance of those changes being merged upstream, or some kind of ES6 shim in front of botkit?
i am actually a contributor of botkit itself, i've been merging botkit's pull requests for the past year
it is pretty hard at the moment to refactor all of the code to ES6 and enable promises
Ahhhh
therefore, a new an a cleaner approach to bot framework itself, seemed a better idea for me
currently, it is just an experiment
we want the word to be out
Neat!
Nice work <@U0HERRQR1>!
ty
<@U04SM6T2H>

owing to the aforementioned daylight savings angst: our bot only sets the user's time zone on first install. Is it a reasonable solution to write a new thing that gets all our user's timezones once per week or something from Slack, and updates them in the database if there's been a change?
yes
We are now rnning ours _nightly_
to keep the timezone info up to date for all users
because people move!
or set their timezone _after_ installing apps

<@U21U8SZ2P> <@U04SM6T2H> , given the nature of our bot, we update the timezone of the user whenever we converse and also daily (in case we havent chatted with them) . Note that we send a lot of contextual reminders so this makes more sense for us.

Also remember not to get caught in the trap if setting scheduled updates for the future where the timezone difference to where you are to where they are may differ compared to that current day e.g UK/US (if comparing between two users, aka 'the calendar problem')

As a bot maker, one of your most important tasks is to design the onboarding. Onboarding for the "champion" (the user who installed the bot) & onboarding for the rest of the team. Hi all, I'd like to create a plug-in that turns specific text into hyperlinks. We develop a ticking system and it is very common for people to post this type of message in slack "Hi Jim, can you check 188877 and tell me if you have seen this issue before". I'd like to create a plugin that turns 188877 into a hyperlink. Can anyone point me in the right direction? What "kind" of plug-in do have to create to do that?
sounds like you want to do it as a custom integration
you could make a slash command, so something like `/widget 188877`, and then it would send a message with the link
or you could do the same thing with an outgoing webhook that listens for some keyword, like `widget`
so if someone says "can you check on widget 188877" it hears the keyword and finds the id and then replies with the link

Hey <@U3AA8RX1V> - there are 2 different types of "bot" apps
1. The "Bot" custom integration - this is setup through "Custom Integrations" section of your slack team - see <http://img.jeremyrace.ca/JvOf>
The "API Token" is the SLACK_BOT_TOKEN
2. If you setup a full blown App and added a bot user, then you need to setup OAuth I think (The nodejs botkit framework has an option for handling OAuth for you, but I think if you're using the Slack Dev. kit then you may need to do it yourself - I'm not familiar with the vanilla slack dev. kit so someone please correct me if I'm wrong)

hey guys, what's the best pattern to invoke a scheduled service with the slack api? sth like checking a specific api call every 30min
<@U101K6JDD> you can use setTimeout (which of course cannot be that exact, but when dealing with 30 minutes and not very granular time, it should be fine)
or you can use node cron libraries
like: <https://www.npmjs.com/package/node-schedule>
depends on how complex you want to make it, but also on what you need to do. As i dont know the details of the project, i can't help more than that

<@U101K6JDD> something like this should do the job:
```function task() {
  yourAPICall();
  setTimeout(task, 1000 * 60 * 30);
}
task();```

with my chat bot, is there a way to see who did an @ at it for my response?
user returns the user id it looks like

```def parse_slack_output(slack_rtm_output): """ The Slack Real Time Messaging API is an events firehose. this parsing function returns None unless a message is directed at the Bot, based on its ID. """ output_list = slack_rtm_output if output_list and len(output_list) > 0: for output in output_list: if output and 'text' in output and AT_BOT in output['text']: # return text after the @ mention, whitespace removed return output['text'].split(AT_BOT)[1].strip().lower(), \ output['channel'], output['user'] return None, None, None```

I am looking to define a Chatbot for passing on Shift handover information

(i) Design a bot and define different labels depending on the category of information that needs to be passed on to next shift as part of Shift Handover. For Example: Labels can be "#Incidentfollowup" , "#KeyThingsToNote#, "#Changealert".
(ii) So, any admin types the information in Slack, which he needs to handover to next shift, and suffix that with one the labels, as defined in example above, plus with a Flag ON or OFF, depending on the validity of that information .The Labels will help Bot program to segregate the information into those categories. So, Whenever admin in the next Shift queries, for example, "@bot which incidents I need to followup on? ", Bot will present the admin with all the information that is tagged under label "#Incidentfollowup" and with Flag ON. Once the task is completed and information is no longer valid , the last admin who completed the task, can set the Flag OFF for that information.

here is the producthunt link: <https://www.producthunt.com/posts/local-guddy>
Let me shortly tell you what we do: <http://www.localguddy.com|www.localguddy.com> is a travel marketplace which connects travelers and locals through unique experiences/tours hosted by locals of the city.
As a local, you can simply create your tour and make money & new friends by showing travelers your city.
We have 4 type of gudd that you can select while creating a tour:
1) Local Guddy: Shows the hidden places of the city like museums, gardens, views etc. 2) Food Walker: Shows the best places in the city to taste local foods in walking distance. 3) Pub Crawler: Shows the night life of the city with the best pubs/clubs. 4) Hommy Chef: Cooks local homemade foods and hosts travelers for a dinner or breakfast.
we have now tours in more than 25 countries! And If you would like to be a guddy as well, you can create your tour on the website :slightly_smiling_face:

<@U3KHRQLTX> correct, there's no way to upload a file (including images) using the RTM API alone. You could include a remote URL to an image within the string component of the message via RTM API, but to actually upload an image you'll need to use `files.upload` from the Web API. If you need to do any kind of advanced message formatting (including message attachments, buttons, etc) you'll need to use something like `chat.postMessage` from the Web API as well.

<@U07CW6N3A> Thank you. I believe if I include a remote URL in string, it has to show up in the message. Whereas, a files.upload with Web API would allow a message plus image uploaded (without showing the URL). Correct?

<@U3KHRQLTX> correct... though the "message" produced by `files.upload` isn't quite purely a message the same way other messages are. For most users, it's close enough but if we're really splitting hairs, `files.upload` results in a file object being created and a _side effect_ of that is something very much like a message object being produced in the channel it was uploaded to/shared to, displaying that image.

An alternative that is more purely a message is to use the `image_url` attribute of a message attachment (as part of creating a message with `chat.postMessage`), pointing to a URL you control: <https://api.slack.com/docs/message-attachments>
<@U07CW6N3A> Perfect, thank you. I think image_url is what I'm after.

Yeah, during oauth, I don't seem to get bot_access_token back. I bet if I postMessage with that, it'll work

<@U3KHRQLTX> make sure you request the `bot` user scope during that flow, then in the OAuth access token response you'll get a bot token in addition to a standard user token (bot token is just for your bot, user token represents the user installing your app). There are also some tricks with using the `as_user` parameter when posting messages that makes things extra confusing. Start with getting the bot user token though, and then use that with `chat.postMessage`.
<@U07CW6N3A> Thank you, I see "bot" on <https://api.slack.com/docs/oauth-scopes> now... under "Slack app scopes" – I overlooked that. Appreciate the tip

You may find you don't need or want all the other "decomposed" scopes like `chat:write:bot` -- a bot user token can use all the methods listed on the <http://api.slack.com/bot-users#api_usage|api.slack.com/bot-users#api_usage> index. If you need to use a method _not_ listed there, that's when you need to ask for the correlating scope and then use the user token instead of the bot token to accomplish it.

Q1. Does 30 RTM (or 50 or 100) connections seem like a lot? Python daemons... I wonder if this warrants using webhooks? Perhaps not, I can't imagine it'd be designed this way if this didn't make sense.

Q4. This is an event for a DM: {'user': 'U02Q9CJN', 'reply_to': 2340, 'ts': '1483064133.000013', 'text': 'ok', 'type': 'message', 'channel': 'D3L6V3F0'} – note the reply_to.
Maybe <@U07CW6N3A> can clarify Q1-4 above too

Q1 - yeah, there's no multiplexing of RTM connections. One open websocket per team you're installed on. Definitely harder to scale. Events API is an alternative, where you get inbound requests for every event and scale your servers/service like a typical inbound web service.

Q2 - our user timezone detail is underdocumented presently. Look for the `tz_offset` field for a better way to adjust your date objects (as well as `tz` -- the "Pacific Standard Time" string you're seeing comes from `tz_label` I believe. . I'm not super familiar with Python tz parsing unfortunately
Q1. Great, thank you

Q3 - yes it's possible you'll get the same message multiple times -- "deliver at least once" is the general failover philosophy. `ts` values are unique per team - channel combination, so if you want to hash them use the team ID and channel ID and the TS value in conjunction with each other. with the events API in particular, you may get dupe events more often (we specifically retry deliveries if you don't respond with a HTTP 200 fast enough)
Q2. tz is empty from what I'm seeing. I wonder if this is a bug, I partly expected US/Pacific to be there
My second option is to use offset, but I can't account for DST with that
Q4 - not sure about this one... it's possible that it's something "extra" the python library is doing or just a stray field in the event that we don't document the usage of
<@U3KHRQLTX> not all users have a specified timezone, so it'll be empty when we don't collect that info from them
the members of my team most experienced with that python lib are on holiday break at the moment unfortunately

Q2. Bingo, I just changed my user to another timezone, then changed it back, and now I see tz': 'America/Los_Angeles', - perfect. I'll use offset first, then that. It's a start, although I don't believe offset can account for DST. I have some ideas to work around this
some day I'll get around to documenting all the TZ behavior (like whether what we do around DSTs) -- apologies that it hasn't happened yet and you have to venture into mystery and miseries

<@U07CW6N3A> I'm grateful I'm even able to engage you here, I can work with what I got. I appreciate your time :slightly_smiling_face:
eg. 'ts': '1483115998.000002' - the .000002 is the unique part
exactly.
That's cool, I've never heard of making timestamps unique in this way
we're leaking our implementation details a little bit this way which makes it harder for things to change later... but you do have a number of benefits from the transparency of it too
<@U07CW6N3A> Great, thank you! :slightly_smiling_face:

<@U3KHRQLTX> the `reply_to` thing -- figured it out, that's just a concern of the RTM API -- each thing you push into the socket gets an identifier, and then the server sends you a response and refers to your push's ID as its `reply_to`. (It's not about message IDs per se): <https://api.slack.com/rtm#ping_and_pong>

<@U07CW6N3A> ohhh, thank you! One thing I was just thinking about – if I want a conversational type bot that is engaged mostly in DM (with no slash commands), then my only option is RTM since webhooks doesn't support DMs, correct?

<@U3KHRQLTX> I think what you really want to use is the Events API: <http://api.slack.com/events-api|api.slack.com/events-api> -- it's more webhook-like but focused on more traditional web app scaling. you'd request the `bot` scope and subscribe to im-related bot events -- you'd only receive messages from IMs that way.

<@U3KHRQLTX> I think your problem is that you're not subscribed to `message.channels`
the `channel_join` message for joining a channel will come from that subscription, you only have `<http://message.im|message.im>`

the message you're seeing when you leave the channel sounds like the DM that slackbot sends you when you're removed from a channel, which is why you're getting it through `<http://message.im|message.im>`
