Or B ) use <http://channels.info|channels.info> and see if my bot user_id is in channel – members

It's hard to have an official recommendation on this... myself -- if I were writing something like this and I wanted _know_ whether I was a member of channel XYZ or not right now, I'd use `<http://channels.info|channels.info>` ad hoc to confirm that. Events API can tell you a lot and give you moment-to-moment updates, but I like the prime knowledge available in a request-and-response approach.

<https://github.com/howdyai/botkit/blob/master/slack_bot.js> I have used the above example of Botkit (It's the simplest one). It's nice and I would like to present it to my teacher but I need to get more info about it's architecture and how it works . So, I can develop it further too. Where & how can I get info about the architecture of Botkit (especially that example)?
<@U3MG3Q1FD> DM incoming

<@U0YB2C09Y> asked for more details so I clarify my question further: I mainly would like to know architectural description of the system illustrating the flow of data between the two systems (Slack and the Botkit module)
i hope there is anyone who can elobarte this to me? :slightly_smiling_face:

<@U3MG3Q1FD> as I said in our DM, `Corebot.js` has the basics of the entire botkit framework, and `Slackbot.js` augments it to work specifically with Slack. Start there and if you have any questions we would love to help you understand better.
Some extra freebies. Botkit uses an Events System to register listeners to specific events that come from the platform you've connected to. These events arrive at a webhook endpoint in all cases except when using Slack RTM API, and are handled according to what platform the message is coming form, and the type of message. Botkit handles conversation management (keeping context between messages, queing messages, creating complex interactions) for you which is a big part of the framework. The docs do a pretty good job of explaining how this works and what botkit is doing. The specifics can be gleaned from reading the code.

Did someone else also noticed that image_url in a message seems to be cached ? when you update the url with a new image and post a new message with the same url referred by image_url, the previous image is displayed as it was cached by slack and not the expected new one
and to you too! if your'e interested in opportunities, # the people foundry ... so I can find you! or DirectMessage Me

Slack support gave quickly the answer for the cache : "That's right, we do cache the contents of image_url and unfortunately there is no way to disable the caching right now. There might be a possible workaround, however. You could use a unique timestamp (or another query string) every time the URL is called, for example: * <https://example.com/image/?time=123456789> * <https://example.com/image/?time=987654321> This should be enough to make Slack fetch the new image each time. Please let me know if you have more questions. " Works fine. Thank you Wojtek Borowic.

Is there a way to get a Slack bot to only allow itself to be in 1 channel? eg. can a slack bot decline an invite into a new channel? If not, I suppose I can have the bot leave if it joins a channel and is already in one via channels.leave

yeah

<@U07CW6N3A> <@U1HK4CCRM> Happen to know if it's possible for a bot to reject an invite to a channel, or not join a channel, or leave a channel? I want to limit my bot to being in 1 channel. I can set it up so my bot is only active in the last channel it was invited to if needed, but I wanted to check with you guys first. Thanks

<@U3KHRQLTX> -- from a pure bot perspective, no -- you'd need to just choose to ignore (or respond with a rote message) messages/events associated with "other" channels -- that's probably not an awesome experience though. I don't recall there being a "kick" method even from a user perspective, so there's no sidebar way to do that through the vehicle of the installing user's access token and an associated scope...

Ultimately, I'd think hard about how you may want someone to install it in only one channel, but a user might want another thing and the platform -- at least at this time -- doesn't provide you an easy means to enforce that. So it may be best to just go with the flow here and allow being in multiple channels, even if you consider only one "primary". But if a user has a good reason to install you in channel XYZ while you're also installed in channel ABC (maybe this user isn't a member of _that_ channel), then maybe your app has a good reason to support both use cases.
<@U07CW6N3A> Thank you for the thoughtful answer – I appreciate it. I'll rethink this process a bit, I can allow for flexibility. :slightly_smiling_face:

The token should be good for whatever scopes you requested it for.
I seem to typically get xoxb for my bot users, and I see xoxp for an app I just made, but I'm not sure it's at all related.

`xoxs` tokens aren't typically for developer use. `xoxb` tokens are for bot users. Usually you'll want to deal with `xoxp` tokens when acting as an app, outside of a bot user context and `xoxb` tokens when acting as a bot user.
I share a file from a cloud service at slack and realized that slack used an `xoxs` token to upload the file, and I wondered what is the difference with the others. Thanks.

probably want to look at direct_mention <@U3PCMK1AA>

```Due to the multi-channel, multi-user nature of Slack, Botkit does additional filtering on the messages (after firing message_received), and will fire more specific events based on the type of message - for example, direct_message events indicate a message has been sent directly to the bot, while direct_mention indicates that the bot has been mentioned in a multi-user channel. List of Slack-specific Events```
Can read more about them here <https://github.com/howdyai/botkit/blob/master/readme-slack.md#slack-specific-events>

Just to be clear: you're using the events API? And your Slack app has requested the `bot` scope as part of installation process. When you receive an event you want to respond to, you create a HTTP POST to `<http://slack.com/api/chat.postMessage|slack.com/api/chat.postMessage>`?
yes, I can receive the event now

If so, simplest thing to do is provide the `token` HTTP/URL parameter as part of the query string, with your bot user's token (starting with `xoxb-`) as the value. The body of your request should still be URL-style parameters too -- it doesn't accept JSON bodies.
It might be that you're trying to post `application/json` to it, which it just doesn't understand right now.
ooooooooooooooooooooo "right now"!
hmm, the document direct me to the `chat.postMessage`...can you give me a right doc link for this thing you described?
yeah...pretty sure I post it as a json body

<@U36JH8YTW> using chat.postMessage to send your message is totally right -- it's just how you send it your message that's very particular. The doc is here <http://api.slack.com/methods/chat.postMessage|api.slack.com/methods/chat.postMessage> (see also <http://api.slack.com/web|api.slack.com/web> ) --- sending JSON is probably why you're getting the error then!
so I should still use the body or they are query parameters style?

<@U36JH8YTW> I recommend in the body, but you can do a mix. `attachments` is the trickiest of the parameters though, as that one takes a URL-encoded _string of JSON_ representing that array. Which sounds crazy I know.
haha~that sounds complicated. But okay, let me try out just respond a simple message <@U07CW6N3A>
Thanks~
Btw, what is the token from the event api use for?

<@U36JH8YTW> that token represents a relationship between Slack -- the platform itself -- and your app. It's kind of like a shared secret (just a different one than that used in OAuth). By validating incoming events you receive contain that token value, you confirm it's coming from Slack's server and not just some rogue server sending you events.
The token used in a request to `chat.postMessage` or other API methods represents your application's relationship to a specific Slack team -- it's for you to identify that relationship and authority to act _to_ Slack.
tokens for me is so clear now :kissing_heart: btw, I can send response now, thanks so much <@U07CW6N3A>

Hi, I am looking for Slack team owners (or administrators) interested in testing an app that simplifies inviting/onboarding new team members. This app provides your Slack team with a dedicated invite landing page that will free you from having to manually invite new members.
Yes, there are a number of other ways to do this (Slackpass, Inviterobot, Slackin, etc.), but the goal of this app is to let non-technical people deploy an invite landing page with no technical background, or special skills. You can customize the look of the landing page, and decide what level of access control (from completely open or manual moderation, to payment and/or invite code being required).
Once again, I'm seeking beta testers prior to submitting the app to the Slack app directory, and if you'd like to check it out please DM me for further details.
<@U0U32UM43> are you hoping that bot owners will spread the word or are you targeting slack users directly?

<@U1DDKQPGB> The app's target audience is team owners, so not directly targeting bot owners really. Mainly posting here because it's where I've seen other similar apps discussed, and where I've been learning about Slack API integration. Also, though it's not ready for testing yet, there will be a bot component to the app as well.

<@U0U32UM43> got it. was asking because I believe bot owners need to educate bot champions on how to educate their users about the bots and why they've been installed. I'm currently thinking about how to help our champions of metacert, to get users used to it. What I've learned recently is that Slack teams don't know who's who and who's doing what. There are multiple admins - who for the best part, don't know how to setup preferences to enable/prevent people from installing bots etc.
<@U0U32UM43> I'd be happy to take your app for a test run for openchatbot.community if you think that's a good use case of a user base
<http://openchatbot.community>

<@U1DDKQPGB> Thanks for your interest. Regarding you comment about multiple admins (or champions) not knowing how to setup bot installation preferences, it would be great to more thoughts on this issues. In particular, do you have any ideas that might help champions and team admins to become more aware of the challenges and opportunities regarding management of bot(s), or other integrations?
<@U0U32UM43> I posted my thoughts on this in openchatbot.community - don't know if it's relevant here as it's mostly dev discussions specifically.
I doont see any reason why that wouldn't be relevant here :smile:. Onboarding is an important piece and crucial to consider for any bot developer.

you're right <@U0V93GE5R> ...
Would love to hear from established bot owners on this one.
I've had a very detailed conversation with a customer who installed MetaCert. And I learned a *massive* load of improvements/changes that we can make - which we couldn't have guessed. His feedback on our installation and configuration process was outstanding - he himself is a security professional. If you'd like to learn how to do slack bot instllation/setup right, check out our metacert.
So... when he installed the bot he immediately was asked by colleagues who and why? They immediately removed the bot because they didn't want it. He wasn't surprised due to their usual response to security generally. So this conversation got me thinking...
We call the person who installs a bot, "champion". bCRM tells us every person's role so we know who all the admins are. My experience of working on both got me thinking about how we could improve the installation/configuration/onboarding process.
What if during setup, we asked the Champion if they'd like to send a DM to the admins with a brief note about the bot and a link, to where they can read more information - in a format that's specifically for them - not a generic webpage on the main site. And in the DM, include who the person is that installed it, with their contact information. This I think, could help to get buy in from the Admins on the team - in the hope it would increase the chances of retention.
What I'm asking for is this, feedback on what you do really well and specifics on your process and messaging.
As you can see from the screen shot, we automate the process of channel selection and service selection.

Is there a way with <http://howdy.ai|howdy.ai> and Microsoft Bot Framework to end a chat session with a user? Or is this something that is not best practice?
you can either use convo.next() or convo.stop(), read more about convo threads hereL <https://github.com/howdyai/botkit/blob/34b44646e95d0abff7dbc96d8a9acbce36f11878/readme.md#conversation-threads>
That doesn't seem to disconnect from the user chat, that just ends the current chat conversation
whats your application/platform?
I am writing Node.js with the <http://Howdy.ai|Howdy.ai> library for use on the Microsoft Bot Framework
what about having your ending thread contain a timeout? <https://github.com/howdyai/botkit/blob/2e6fd61a6c0754be62f31e563c2de4739502e59d/slack_bot.js#L191>
That would kill the node.js process. I want the bot to still be running, but I just want the current session to end with a user.
well it depends a little on what platform you are running your bot, where is the bot going to live?
for example, on slack rtm, you always want to leave the session open so your bot is available.

kz i don't believe there are mechanisms provided to like, close the chat window when your bot is done. closing the conversation on their end is entirely up to the user on all the platforms i can think of.
what i can recommend is make it clear the conversation, as far as your bot is considered, is completed. in howdy, we use :wave: or ttyl.
Ahhh thanks. The bot will live on a webpage using <https://github.com/Microsoft/BotFramework-WebChat>.
ah ok! there might be a way to close it there, i haven't played with that much.

I'm reading the Oauth documentation (<https://api.slack.com/docs/oauth>) and in the hook back to my API, I would like the profile details of the user who authenticated. In making the request `<https://slack.com/oauth/authorize>?....` is there anyway that I can request slack to send the profile details of the authenticating user when it makes a request to my redirect hook?
<@U419E6R60>: unfortunately, you have to make an additional user info call after you get the token.
Yeah in authing when I pass `identity.*` and any other scopes I get an error message

``` Invalid permissions requested Cannot request both identity scopes and other scopes at the same time
```

I notice this error message when I add `identity.*` scopes and other scopes when requesting a page for the user to auth: ``` Invalid permissions requested Cannot request both identity scopes and other scopes at the same time ```
this is after makign this request `<https://slack.com/oauth/authorize>?`
why can I not request both identity scopes and other scopes?

Unfortunately, at this time you need to perform the round trip twice -- the identity scopes are _exclusive_ in that they can only be requested on their own without other scopes. But if you go ahead in a second trip to oauth/authorize requesting the other scopes you want, they'll be added on to the existing token progressively
I've been trying to find a reason but I cannot find it

The reason why is that Sign in with Slack is a kind of product of its own that just happens to run on the same OAuth used to install apps. That installing an app and Signing in to one are two distinct activities. It can be confusing.
i see...ok thank you <@U07CW6N3A>
It trips enough folks up that I think it's likely you'll find that seemingly artificial separation bridged one day.
Yeah I was intuitively putting that understanding together seeing as that there is a `sign in` with slack button and `an add to slack ` button
suggesting two different APIs...
Thank you for the clarification
It's far too subtle. Your intention is clear when you combine them.

yes tunneling with ngrok

what scopes does your app have when posting?
one way to debug a little is to turn the web inspector on in your slack -- easiest via web -- and look closer at the error that happens when you click the button.
more often than not, that error is because the message was posted from a webhook, bot, or slash command that wasn't actually part of the app, or the app doesn't have the scope to do those things.
in that case it doesn't know where to send the action to because the message is disembodied from the slack app.
if you're still having trouble and have checked all this, recommend moving on to Slack's great support team that can help look deeper at the specifics of your setup.

Hey have a question regarding the `ts` field in a slack message. Why is there a decimal value?
this issue tries to explain it -> <https://github.com/slackhq/slack-api-docs/issues/7>
also, how does slack create an epoch time like that?
i've never seen one with a decimal value
<@U419E6R60> it's a pretty painful quirk in slack data, it's an attempt to make a unique id for messages
ok so it is not necessary to include a time stamp when sending messages -- i was worried that i would have to make a timestamp like the above
Technically they're fraction notation, but practically it's for uniqueness
they act as both a message timestamp and a message ID when combined with another ID, e.g. `channel_id` + `ts`
we don't recommend relying entirely on `ts` for uniqueness due to possible (but unlikely) ID collisions

See Paul's response on that gh issue: >>>The first are properties that are unix timestamps, usually indicating when something was created or updated, usually called “created” or “edited”. These should all be integers (although it's possible, despite checking several times recently, that we've missed one).
The second are the message timestamps, which always use the “ts” name (eg: “ts”, “event_ts”). These are returned as strings. Even though they look like floats, they should always be stored and compared as strings - because floats occasionally lose precision and that would be bad here.
The bit after the decimal point is a sequence that guarantees uniqueness and ordering:
A message in a channel will have a unique TS for that channel (two messages in two different channels can have the same TS). If message A is posted before message B then A's TS will be less than B's. Knowing all that, it becomes clear that the “timestamp” property on files is badly named. We've just introduced a new “created” property that better describes what it is, which will be returned by our APIs from today onwards. We'll maintain backwards compatibility by supporting the old “timestamp” property too.
Thanks

Or if it can be used to respond to what's typed in the menu box? I want to use it to display search results of a sort
A static collection or one provided in a single external suggestions/options load URL can have up 100 options!

But with the typeahead feature, we'll send you an options load request once a certain number of characters have been typed, that will include the query as a `value`, which you can then use in conjunction with the engaging user, channel, etc. to build a list of 100 options in response to the query. So you can accomplish a search box of sorts that way

Hey guys, I'm a beginner and I'm finding it challenging understanding how the tokens work
I looked at the API and still can't get my bot to do something.. Any ideas?
Basically I can perform the `channels.kick` method with my own token, but not the bot's.. even after I add the `channel.write` permission.. Not sure whats the matter

<@U54NT1NMR> Hi! The token system is a little confusing! Bot users are represented by the bot user token and the `bot` scope, which affords it a short list of permissions and methods the bot can call on its own behalf. It can do all these things on the web API checked in the right hand column: <https://api.slack.com/bot-users#method_list>

<@U54NT1NMR> Bot tokens only have the permissions in that list. They can't gain additional permissions, even if you have ask for them during the installation sequence.
user tokens, on the other hand, represent the user who installed the app, and its relationship with your app/bot. The user token can use almost any method in the Web API, provided it has the right scopes assigned to it. So if you ask for the `channels:write` permission during installation, it only applies to the user token.

The `bot` scope doesn't afford bot user tokens the ability to leave/create or kick members from channels. If your app really needs to do something that a bot user isn't permissioned to do, you'll need to swap to a user token bearing the permissions you need whenever performing that action. Because the vehicle of the action will be the user's identity, instead of it looking as if your bot "kicked" a member from a channel, it'll appear as if the user who installed your app did it.
Ah, I see... So I am forced to use a user token to do that functionality. Makes sense now. I thought I was implementing the tokens wrong in my application at first.
I guess I can create a second user with a dummy name, I just didn't want everybody hearing that I was kicking them from channels :slightly_smiling_face:. Bad rep and all... lol
Thank you <@U07CW6N3A>
<@U54V8P5QD> <@U0GT29N3A> the `rtm.connect` presence issue should be corrected, at least the next time you open up a connection via that method. Let me know if you still have trouble.
thanks, will check
works!

How to use `outgoing webhook url` in case of slack app as they've mentioned outgoing webhook won't work in case of slack `app` and suggested to use `Event Api`. But i was wondering how can i use the webhook url in event api. I'm not just thinking out loud.. any idea!
you're right, outgoing webhooks aren't supported as part of a Slack app.

Events API offers some similar functionality. The Request URL on _your server_ where Slack will deliver events is kind of like a "webhook URL". While you can't ask the events API to only notify that URL when certain text matches are found, you can subscribe to broader events and then filter and focus only on the events containing text you're interested in server-side, in your own code.

Ok Here is the answer, The event that slack triggers on successful installation, contains the UserID of the user that installed the app. This user ID can be used to send a welcome message to the user. It was quite simple I guess, I want just not thinking . Just realized it :slightly_smiling_face:

{"ok":true,"access_token":"xxxx","scope":"identify,bot,","user_id":"xxxx","team_name":"xx","team_id":"xx","incoming_webhook":{"channel":"<#C04SM6TAK|general>","channel_id":"xxxxxx","configuration_url":"xxxxx","url":"xxxxx"},"bot":{"bot_user_id":"xxxxx","bot_access_token":"xxxxx"}}

<@U584CEHS9> — you question might relate to one I was asking, yesterday, regarding getting botkit to scale up on different dynos in heroku (automatically, with minimal effort).
It seems that getting this to work would require that the `<http://slack.com|slack.com>` APIs forward a “session affinity” token, encoded in a cookie, such that an ongoing “conversation” can continue to target the same dyno instance: <https://devcenter.heroku.com/articles/session-affinity>
…It seems that Slack APIs may have insufficient support for this.
BTW, some analogue of “session affinity” might be required in order to ensure that a bot “conversation” proceeds in the same server process. (regardless of whether you're using heroku)

So... I'm building a HR bot that manages anonymous feedback for teams - DM the bot, and it passes feedback along. I know that an initial DM to the team on install is pure evil, but is it as evil if the HR manager initiates the push (sending an initial private survey)?
(deciding if I should let that be an option, or not allow global surveys, broad pushes, etc. - trying to balance team UX against helping HR encourage participation)
I don't want to be tina.

sstrad: yo! I worked on Howdy, a bot we made to run meetings in Slack. I don't think there's anything wrong with having your admin user/HR manager initiate the push. we initially DM the owner (user who installed the bot) just to talk through basic bot functionality, and then that user can decide to run the meeting on entire channels or specific users. I think that's a pretty good way to approach it.
Awesome - might be good to have the admin push a note/explanation to <#C04SM6TAK|general> as well (so it's not a surprise to everyone)

Yeah! That was a feature we talked about building into Howdy, but got a bit distracted. Ha. I think it would be cool if, once the admin knew the bot functionality, you hit a button that dispatched the bot to introduce itself to <#C04SM6TAK|general> with a similar explanation. I think you're on it!

You can onboard your "champion" (the intial user that adds a bot to a team) via dm, and give them a yes/no "would you like me to introduce myself in a channel?" Sorta flow. Just ask permission, explain what they will set in motion, and give the hr manager the option to select a channel to introduce the bot in. My two cents

But yeah do not auto dm everyone on bot team join, nobody likes that and its a bad first impression. Another option is an @ channel when the bot introduces itself, inviting people to DM it themselves.
You are then inviting folks to participate, and if they dont have a first interaction with the bot for a couple weeks, maybe send a reminder DM, just once, to remind them the bot is there
Ultimately, HR should have more swing than your bot in terms of influencing behavior of the employees, ie interacting with the bot Lean on the leverage your champion has as a human on the team
Cool - thanks! This feels close to what I had in mind - have HR person introduce the bot and trigger DMs (if wanted) or allow users to send feedback in via /command.
Nervous about allowing feedback outside of DMs, though, b/c I don't want someone to screw up the command in <#C04SM6TAK|general> and post a rant where everyone can see it:scream:

Is there any advantage of using RTM API if you plan to scale your bot to thousands of teams, (the Events API seems much better for this use case)? Seems to me that managing hundreds of websockets would be a nightmare and also costly. Are there any devs who still prefer the RMT over Events, would love to hear your reasons!
I've read this <https://api.slack.com/faq#events_api> but I'm curious for any devs that have done work with both
vikyan: From what I understand, not all api features are available in Events, so depending on your bots function, you might not be able to easily change from an RTM to events powerd bot.
Its way easier to scale a Events bot however, for the reason you pointed out.

<@U0V93GE5R> that makes sense. Seems like the two APIs will have pretty much the same features eventually and maybe it's just me, but the offical Slack docs push more towards the Events API as up and coming
Are there any botkit examples using the Events API? Most examples here: <https://github.com/howdyai/botkit/tree/master/examples> are build using the RTM
no, we need to make some! The slack starter kit is events focused though! <https://github.com/howdyai/botkit-starter-slack>

<@U0Z1RH1QX> For my particular use case using RTM was a huge headache. I spent countless hours trying to debug stale connections and re-spawning the connection.
As far as I know the only thing RTM gives you the ability to show your bot as online/offline if your app crashes as well as the ability to add a "typing" indicator.
If you want something to just work, I'd recommend using the Events API exclusively ( I totally could just be doing things wrong )

<@U4T0WR6EM> yeah that was mine impression too. Slack also just added the whole online/offline indicator for events too so that shouldn't be an issue. Coming from The Messenger API which is Events based, that approach seems more manageable over websockets
definitely use Events API
RTM is being slowly phased out
<@U04SM6T2H> Awesome thank you for that info!

We support around 15,000 active teams right now, and use both RTM and Events. Unfortunately, there are lots of different reasons that Slack will simply disable the events API for your integration. For this reason, we process every message via _both_ events and RTM, and deduplicate it internally. It's painful, but unfortunately no other way to make a resilient slack integration that we've found.

There are also a number of things which aren't possible in events (which we need the RTM connection for in any case).
I'd imagine in the future, the events API will become more reliable, and we'll be able to completely decommission our RTM

<@U0Z1RH1QX> long story short: RTM API is what you want to use when you build a Slack client (e.g. mobile app), Event API is what you want to use when you build an app/bot on a dynamically scaling infrastucture.

For reference here is my Bot service that manages the connection to Slack and set's up the webhook endpoints. Currently I have this in production and I haven't had any issues so far!
<https://gist.github.com/clintonhalpin/3bd3d7e8f47371c34b4a49f51dea398f>
<@U4MTCT79C> I'm curious what you need specifically from RTM that you're not getting via the events API, just presence changes?
Heya <@U0JK287M2> - some of the team-based settings.
Although, yes, it can be used for presence and adding the “@blah is typing…” indicator (we don't use these specifically though)
The RTM API also gives an immediate indication if your integration has been disabled, whereas I'm not 100% sure if there is a specific event for this.
Ah, as in when you're disconnected? That makes sense, we're working on providing better clarity on that via the Events API :ok_hand:
Which team-based settings do you mean? Data you're getting out of `rtm.start`?

I have a slackbot in nodejs running on 3 machines..and my issue is that when i talk to the bot, i get 3 responses from each of these machines..I have setup an LB, but I am not sure where to provide this url of my LB in the slack app. Could someone provide suggestions
<@U50V26V7W> you'd need to make sure the request only goes to one host behind the LB
<@U272P5K71> yes..so is there a way to add the LB url to slack app anywhere? How do I redirect the request to the LB
no, your load balancer would be the URL Slack hits, and would then delegate the requests to the hosts behind it
Like in this basic diagram, your LB would be the first line of processing: <http://www.maxnoc.com/images/diagram/load-balancing.gif>
<@U272P5K71> yes i understand that, but where do I give the LB url??
the LB url would just be the `Request URL`
we don't have a specific path for it
Slack doesn't know whether you have a balencer or a single host, it just sends to the Request URL or Action URL for menus/buttons
anyone know of a good UI components library for building out messenger webviews?

<@U0JK287M2> we try to mirror as many of a team's slack settings as possible - for example, whether messages can be deleted, the grace period that a message can be edited within, whether file uploads are enabled, whether to display real names or user names. This auto-configures busybot to make onboarding really quick and simple. When we implemented the Events API from memory these type of settings weren't all visible via the events API (although it was a different dev on our team who implemented that so I'm not 100% sure that I'm correct here, or whether it has changed since).
The biggest issue for us with decommissioning RTM is the fact that the Events API can get completely disabled without warning. When this happens, the bot is completely disabled and there is no way to automatically re-enable it (other than get a telephone call, wake up, and manually switch it back on). This has happened perhaps 10 times for us, and completely disables the bot for every team. For example, when there was a change to the app store listing, we would receive ~30,000 events all within the space of 1-2 seconds, and because we didn't respond with a `200` within 3 seconds to all of those requests, the events were disabled. Similarly, we recently experienced an issue where events were running ~10 minutes behind real-time, so users thought the bot was unresponsive (in reality we were just receiving messages 10 minutes late). Finally, we do get rate limited for large teams / enterprise grid teams, where the volume of events requests exceeds the rate limit, often for hours at a time. For these reasons, we need to keep many thousands of RTM connections open 24x7, as a fallback for the events API. Hope this makes sense?
(Sorry about the slow reply - I'm based in Western Australia)

BTW, we would absolutely love to decommission our RTM cluster, and move fully to events. It would make our lives easier! We've raised a few support tickets with Slack about these issues, but I understand that they aren't on the radar to get resolved. So unfortunately, for now, it's both events + RTM for us. More than happy to hop on a quick call to discuss, and I can bring along Felix who wrote all of our RTM API code and most of our events API code too. Feel free to DM me :slightly_smiling_face:

Ah, just spoke to Felix and we do receive a `user_change` event which says the bot is deleted. So that's not too much of a problem currently, and wouldn't prevent us from decommissioning the RTM.
We use the following information from rtm start / events: `team.name`, `team.domain`, `team.plan`, `prefs.msg_edit_window_mins`, `prefs.allow_message_deletion`, `prefs.display_real_names`, `prefs.disable_file_uploads`
He also said that please, please, please can we put in a request to get these three events on the plan somewhere :stuck_out_tongue: : a) When a public channel is converted into a group (currently there is no event, so all we can do is read the text of the message sent to us by slackbot, and parse that, which is pretty awful) b) When the bot is kicked out of a channel c) When the bot is kicked out of a group

bug? when I get a user info using the api tester, I get an email field in the profile. But if I use the rest api, I don't, everything else is there.

API tester tokens have maximal permissions. Using the web API with standard tokens, you'll need to have the `users:read.email` scope to access that field: <http://api.slack.com/changelog/2017-04-narrowing-email-access|api.slack.com/changelog/2017-04-narrowing-email-access> and <http://api.slack.com/changelog/2016-11-10-addressing-email-addresses|api.slack.com/changelog/2016-11-10-addressing-email-addresses> have more detail.

Are threads supported in the Events API?

probably not a scoping issue.. are you sure when you're using `chat.postMessage` via token you're specifying a `thread_ts` that is not itself a reply to another message?
Have you tried using a message that doesn't involve using <@USLACKBOT>?
Yes, there are events about threaded messages available in the events API -- message subtypes `message_replied` being the one you most likely want.
Yes, the thread_ts is set to the parent ts. When using the same ts in the Tester, it works
Not sure I understand your last reply. I can't use chat.postMessage in event API?

the events API is just about sending your app "what happened" -- there's no write aspect to it. For write operations, you're meant to use it conjunction with a Web API method like `chat.postMessage`.
What scopes does the token you're using have? It's possible it just doesn't have the scopes needed to write messages with what you're working with.
I'm using chat.postMessage, and it's working fine. When adding the thread_ts attribute, it just does not change anything, still working like before, still normal message, not threaded replies
and you're including `thread_ts` as a URL parameter in this case? What's the `channel` field set to and `as_user` value set to? Are you using a bot token or a user token?
I'm using my Slack App token. as_user is set to false and channel is set to @user (user being whatever user the Slack App is talking too)
btw, thank you for helping me out here :slightly_smiling_face:.

It _might_ be a quirk with using a @username in that field -- it's a little bit on the edge of typical behavior. Normal usage typically will use a specific IM/direct message ID there, a channel ID, a private channel ID, or an MPIM ID.
Just to be sure, since it sounds like you're using a user token, what are the scopes you asked for when you made it?

```users:read.email identify channels:read channels:history channels:write dnd:read team:read emoji:read files:read groups:read groups:history chat:write:bot im:read im:history mpim:history pins:read reactions:read stars:read usergroups:read team:read users:read im:write im:write mpim:write pins:write reactions:write reactions:read reminders:write reminders:read stars:write users.profile:read usergroups:write usergroups:read users:read users.profile:read```

I'm out of ideas! Our support team might be able to figure it out more deeply for you using more specifics from your team and logs if you want to reach out: <http://api.slack.com/support|api.slack.com/support> -- it's a little strange it works with a tester token, which makes me think that somehow you're specifying thread_ts in a way that we're just not understanding. The @username/slackbot approach might also be part of the issue. Using a bot token instead of the user token might help a lot, but that changes the rules a bit at the same time to only invited conversations.

Hi, does anyone know of a easy way to grab a user's information (like first or full name) with only a slash command?

<@U5SL9NDRB> you'd need to use the web API in conjunction with your slash command to retrieve that kind of extended information. Most commonly, folks either have a bot user and use that token, or you ask for the `users:read` scope and use the user token you receive during installation to occasionally poll `users.list` and keep the maps in memory OR look up on demand by user ID with `<http://users.info|users.info>`.
Yeah, I was trying to do that as well but I keep messing up somewhere and everything is always undefined. I don't suppose you know of a readily available example of such an API call?

<@U5SL9NDRB> In Python: ``` from slackclient import SlackClient
slack_token = "YOUR_BOTS_OAUTH_TOKEN" sc = SlackClient(slack_token)
sc.api_call( user="U1234567890", ) ```

Failed to complete tunnel connection
The connection to REDACTED was successfully tunneled to your ngrok client, but the client failed to establish a connection to the local address localhost:8080.
Make sure that a web service is running on localhost:8080 and that it is a valid address.
The error encountered was: dial tcp [::1]:8080: connectex: No connection could be made because the target machine actively refused it.
Using `ngrok http 3000` instead of `ngrok http 80` seems to have taken care of the tunneling issue but, the bot is still not replying. I'm not getting the bad gateway messages anymore.

It seems I have solved the last piece of the puzzle. I was not providing the secret while creating the webhooks. I've got the welcome message, "I am a bot, here to do your bidding." e.g. Let's say I'm connecting to 1000 Slack teams using websockets. I need to spread that load to a max of 100/server (hypothetical)

<@U3NFQN97H>: There is no other value for now, It's a placeholder for future features
<@U500C4E05>: to make it more complicated, also check out: <https://github.com/BeepBoopHQ/slapp>

I personally don't like botkit's approach. You end up writing different bots for different platforms anyways. Go for somehting Slack specific and always uptodate with the API features. Will make your life easier from my experience.
<@U6330SLE9>: yes that's true. You are expected to respond within 3 seconds.

When your response requires some time to be processed (e.g. when generating a statistic) then reply immediately with a message that states that you are currently processing the request and update or respond to this messages when you have your result.

When you are having trouble to respond within 3 seconds even when your use case is simple then you should look into why your performance is so bad. You should aim for 100ms response time for standard responses in production mode. When testing locally using tunnels you might run into this limit from time to time though. Just ignore it.

Hey all, 100% new to bots. I want to relay messages between a slack channel and hangout/groupme. Can you point me in the right direction?

your best bet will be some kind of middleground of using a browser-based tool like "Postman" or by using a console-based tool like `curl`.
For testing messages as vanilla as possible by just copying and pasting the JSON from message builder, I'd create an incoming webhook and then just send that JSON to the URL using curl like this:
`curl -X POST -H "Content-type: application/json" INCOMING_WEBHOOK_URL --data "{ // all your JSON }"`
There's some easier/harder variants where you put the JSON in a file and reference it instead.
With something like postman, you'll have a field for a URL (your incoming webhook URL) and the ability to easily just say "I'm posting JSON" and copy and paste it into a box hit send and check out the result.
